sense.def: used before a noun to refer to a single thing or person but not a particular thing or person or not one that you have referred to before
dictionaryExamples: She's got a boyfriend.
Someone left an umbrella here yesterday.
Is he a friend of yours?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: used to mean any or every thing or person of the type you are referring to
dictionaryExamples: Can you ride a bike?
A child needs love.
A cheetah can run faster than a lion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't need it because I'm too old to have a doll. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: one
dictionaryExamples: a hundred dollars
a dozen eggs
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Ally, All my friends [from] school were here, more than a hundred people. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to state what type of thing or person something or someone is
dictionaryExamples: Sally's an engineer.
It's a rabbit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's a teacher. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tamil

sense.def: used before some phrases saying how much of something there is
dictionaryExamples: a few days
a little bit of yarn
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually people in Poland are very busy so we do not have a lot of time for cooking. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: used before some action nouns when referring to one example of the action
dictionaryExamples: Take a look at this, Jez.
I'm just going to take a ride.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took a shower and ate my breakfast. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: used before the first but not the second of two nouns that are often used together
dictionaryExamples: a cup and saucer
a knife and fork
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like a clean fork and knife. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: used when referring to a unit of something, especially something you eat or drink
dictionaryExamples: I'd love a coffee.
All I had for lunch was a yogurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We both had a coke and a hot dog. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used between a fraction and a unit of measurement
dictionaryExamples: half a mile
a quarter of a kilo
three-quarters of an hour
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lesson is half an hour but you have to be ther[e] 10 minutes before. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: used when referring to a certain period of time
dictionaryExamples: Take one tablet three times a day.
She earns $100,000 a year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can write to him or her twice a week. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to leave someone or something somewhere, sometimes not returning to get them
dictionaryExamples: They were forced to abandon the car.
My sister abandoned me at the station, so I went home alone.
We were sinking fast, and the captain gave the order to abandon ship.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All at once, they abandoned their sacks of stolen property and ran for their lives! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to stop doing something before it is finished, or to stop following a plan, idea, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The weather was so bad, we abandoned our plans for a picnic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How would you feel if you establish[ed] a long-time plan for your career and then you ha[d] to abandon it? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: left empty or not working
dictionaryExamples: an abandoned house/building/mine
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Arriving [at] an altitude of 2000m, people can visit the abandoned salt-mines. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: having been left somewhere, intentionally
dictionaryExamples: An abandoned baby was left at the hospital.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, just have a look [at] your wife Margaret and her eyes will tell you that she is this abandoned princess of your childhood fairy-tale. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the physical or mental skill or qualities that you need to do something
dictionaryExamples: She had the ability to explain things clearly.
athletic/academic ability
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The protagonist had been bitten by a strange spider and some days later, he noticed [he had] some strange powers, such as the ability to create spider[s'] webs. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: different from what is normal or usual, in a way which is strange or dangerous
dictionaryExamples: abnormal behavior/conditions
We had an abnormal amount of snow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You are all obliged to inform other worker[s] about the danger if you should notice anything that is abnormal. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: on or onto a plane, ship, bus, or train
dictionaryExamples: Once everyone was aboard the plane, the doors were closed and the crew prepared for takeoff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While the food aboard your aircraft was regarded as excellent in 2004, its quality has dropped significantly this year. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to officially end something, especially a law or system
dictionaryExamples: I think bullfighting should be abolished.
National Service was abolished in Britain in 1962.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, I suggest you should not change or abolish any event for any reason. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a medical method to end a pregnancy
dictionaryExamples: to have an abortion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of these problems are serious and should be eliminated, such as abortion and domestic violence. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: relating to a particular subject or person
dictionaryExamples: What's she talking about?
I've got a book about Jung.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used when suggesting or offering something to someone
dictionaryExamples: How about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"
How about cycling there?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What about going on Saturday? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: What  about Ava - is she nice?
So the town was nice - how about the food?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also enjoy shopping for shoes, what about you? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a little more or less than the stated number or amount
dictionaryExamples: It happened about two months ago.
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's not far [from]  my home, about 20 minut[es'] walk, [or] 5 minut[es] by bus. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai

sense.def: to be going to do something very soon
dictionaryExamples: I was about to leave when Mark arrived.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm in a hurry, my class is about to begin. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: in or to a higher position than something else
dictionaryExamples: There's a mirror above the sink.
Her name comes above mine on the list.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have [put]  it above the bookshelf. Key English Test; A2; Assamese

sense.def: more than an amount or level
dictionaryExamples: It says on the box it's for children age three and above.
Rates of pay are above average.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is too hot in Beijing. Every day [it] is above 30 degrees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: most importantly
dictionaryExamples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
He is known above all for his movies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a very nice person and above all, she is really cheerful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: too good or important for something
dictionaryExamples: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

sense.def: higher on the page
dictionaryExamples: the above diagram
Match these words with the pictures above.
Please send the articles to the address given/shown above.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can be contacted at the above address and I would be free to attend an interview at any time from Monday to Saturday. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in or to a foreign country
dictionaryExamples: He's gone abroad on business.
We always go abroad in the summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have never been abroad. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: sudden and not expected
dictionaryExamples: Our conversation came to an abrupt end/halt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their income came from the revenues obtained by selling milk, fruit, jelly and other perishable goods, but they had to pay John, or their happy lifestyle would come to an abrupt end. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: dealing with people in a quick, direct way that is unfriendly or rude
dictionaryExamples: She can be rather abrupt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was poorly received and the general tone of the person assisting me was rude and abrupt. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: suddenly and quickly
dictionaryExamples: They abruptly left the party.
His speech ended abruptly and he left the stage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she became an adolescent, her perspective changed abruptly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone is not where they are usually expected to be
dictionaryExamples: A new manager was appointed during/in her absence.
She has had repeated absences from school this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, during your absence, the T.V. repair man never appear[ed] and I had to insist by phone on your behalf. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when something does not exist
dictionaryExamples: He drew attention to the absence of concrete evidence against the defendant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The biggest difference the absence of TV made in my life was that I actually started living. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: not in the place where you are expected to be, especially at school or work
dictionaryExamples: John has been absent from school/work for three days now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to be absent because my grandmother is ill and I have to take care of her. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: complete and definite
dictionaryExamples: absolute power/control
That's absolute nonsense!
Repairing the heating system is an  absolute necessity!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have no experience in surfing - I am an absolute beginner with high motivation. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: The food was absolutely delicious.
It's absolutely ridiculous.
I have absolutely no idea what she's talking about.
We've achieved absolutely nothing today.
I absolutely hate it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've heard the film is absolutely fantastic. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: used to strongly agree with someone
dictionaryExamples: "Do you think it helped his career?" "Absolutely."
"It was an excellent movie, though." "Absolutely!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So don't you think it was unfair and little rude to say that in your newspaper? Absolutely. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: used to strongly disagree with someone or to agree with something negative
dictionaryExamples: "Are you suggesting that we should just ignore the problem?" "No, absolutely not."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Does it mean the parents will allow them to eat anything they please? Absolutely not. You have to give the children some options, instead of imposing things on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to take something in, especially gradually
dictionaryExamples: Plants absorb carbon dioxide.
The drug is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything is getting intermingled and absorbed into the system, making life terribly efficient, quick and easy. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to give all your attention to something that you are doing
dictionaryExamples: Simon was so absorbed in his computer game that he didn't notice me come in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We hadn't noticed them at first because we were absorbed in [listening to the] birds singing. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to understand and remember facts that you read or hear
dictionaryExamples: It's hard to absorb so much information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will have only three school [subjects] and that'[ll] make it easier to absorb the new knowledge. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: relating to ideas and not real things
dictionaryExamples: abstract ideas
Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Reading improve[s] your ability to imagine and your abstract thinking skills. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Abstract art involves shapes and colors and not images of real things or people.
dictionaryExamples: abstract paintings/sculpture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What kind of material will you use for this painting? Will it be a realistic picture or an abstract one? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: very silly
dictionaryExamples: What an absurd explanation!
Don't be so absurd! Of course I want you to come.
It's an absurd situation - neither of them will talk to the other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not a big city and I think it's absurd that people that live and work in it use the car to go to school or to work. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: bad or cruel treatment of people or animals
dictionaryExamples: sexual/psychological/mental abuse
The rescued dogs had been victims of physical abuse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The one side opposes this treatment as an abuse of living creatures while the other side denies any suffering and points at the values of zoos for people. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the  use of a substance in an unsuitable and harmful way or for the wrong purpose
dictionaryExamples: Drug and alcohol abuse  contributed to his early death.
This program tries to address problems that lead to substance abuse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Get information about the [effect]s of drug abuse and make your generation a better one. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an action or activity that is morally wrong or not allowed
dictionaryExamples: The mayor was suspected of corruption and other abuses.
The committee is investigating the abuse of tax-exempt status by charities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a vast resource of information, but the abuse of it may have detrimental consequences. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: rude and offensive words said to another person
dictionaryExamples: He found it difficult to tolerate the verbal abuse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went all the way back cycling on the wrong side of the road, and anyone who said something about it could expect a stream of abuse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: saying rude and offensive words to someone
dictionaryExamples: an abusive phone call
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is partly true, because even [a] slightly abusive expression might result in discord or [rupture] between seemingly close friends. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: relating to schools, colleges, and universities, or to subjects that involve thinking and studying and not technical or practical skills
dictionaryExamples: academic subjects/programs/institutions
academic standards/achievement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a member of our academic community,  I'm very glad to hear that our college will have a surplus in its annual budget. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to start to happen more quickly, or to make something start to happen more quickly
dictionaryExamples: Inflation is likely to accelerate this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fashion has always been changing but I think this process accelerated after the Second World War. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Hungarian

sense.def: to move or cause yourself or a vehicle to move faster
dictionaryExamples: The car in front accelerated and left us behind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I ride my bike and start accelerating, I feel that I move with the speed of the wind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the way in which people in a particular area, country or social group pronounce words
dictionaryExamples: a Boston/Southern accent
He speaks with a heavy/strong Russian accent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our teacher is a middle-aged lady with a kind smile and [a] British accent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a mark written or printed over a letter to show you how to pronounce it
dictionaryExamples: There's an acute accent on the "e" of "café."

sense.def: to agree to take something that is offered to you
dictionaryExamples: to accept an apology/invitation/offer
I've been invited to their wedding, but I haven't decided whether to accept.
She won't accept advice from anyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope that you accept my apology. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to admit that something is true, often something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: He refuses to accept that he's made a mistake.
I can't accept that there's nothing we can do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David told her that the reason [for] his failure was her, because she used to press him  a lot and she couldn't accept that he wanted to be an actor. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to allow someone to join an organization or become part of a group
dictionaryExamples: She was accepted to two of the universities she applied to.
He was accepted as a full member of the society.
His fellow workers refused to accept him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I returned home I check[ed] my mail and I ha[d] a new message from my uncle, saying that the university have accepted me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to admit that you caused something bad that happened
dictionaryExamples: I accept full responsibility for the failure of the plan.

sense.def: good enough
dictionaryExamples: This kind of behavior is not acceptable.
We need an arrangement that is acceptable to both parties.
So what is an acceptable level of radiation?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure that finally I will succeed in [us]ing English in an acceptable way! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: allowed or approved of
dictionaryExamples: It's not socially acceptable to wear jeans and a T-shirt to a wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They should teach them what is right [and] wrong, and what is morally and socially acceptable. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when you accept something
dictionaryExamples: His acceptance of the award was controversial.
There is a growing public  acceptance of alternative medicine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main reason for the "fast-food" groceries winning acceptance in Swedish culture is lack of time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: agreed with or approved of by most people
dictionaryExamples: an accepted spelling
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Competition can also be an accepted form of expression of one's aggression. International English Language Testing System; C1; Others

sense.def: the right or opportunity to use or look at something
dictionaryExamples: Internet access
The system has been designed to give the user quick and easy access to the required information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would suggest free Internet access as an extra facility in our library. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: the way in which you can enter a place or get to a place
dictionaryExamples: disabled access
The only access to the island is by boat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [I]t will be tempting for the companies in town to move out where there is more space for expansion and easier access by trucks and cars. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to find or see information, especially using a computer
dictionaryExamples: You can access the files over the Internet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have more time to stay together at home,  because we can access [the] internet at home. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: able to be reached or easily gotten
dictionaryExamples: The island resort is accessible by plane or ferry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The museum is near the city center and is accessible by bus or walking. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: easy to understand
dictionaryExamples: They are attempting to make opera accessible to a wider audience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Jacques Prevert, the French poet, changed our way [of seeing] the world by making poetry accessible to everyone.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something extra that is not necessary but is attractive or useful
dictionaryExamples: home/desk accessories
fashion accessories
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They find pleasure in looking at different clothes, shoes, accessories, gadgets and home furnishings. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: something bad which happens that is not expected or intended, and which causes injury or damage
dictionaryExamples: Josh had an accident and spilled water all over the floor.
She was injured in a car/traffic accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had an accident two weeks ago and now I can't do sport. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: without being intended
dictionaryExamples: I deleted the file by accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was dancing and someone [kicked me] by accident and my glasses fell [off]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: happening by chance
dictionaryExamples: accidental damage
The archeological site was located after the accidental discovery of bones in a field.

sense.def: by chance or by mistake
dictionaryExamples: She accidentally knocked over a glass of water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I accidentally broke one of your vases - the most beautiful one. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: praised by a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: the acclaimed singer and songwriter
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In order to avoid s[uch an] embarrassing inconsistency in the next meeting, I suggest inviting Colin Briggs, the acclaimed footballer, to talk to his fans. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a place to stay such as a hotel room
dictionaryExamples: Tour operators are advertising accommodations as low as $79 per night in first-class hotels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Concerning the accommodations, I prefer a cabin rather than to sleep in a tent. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to go somewhere with someone
dictionaryExamples: We accompanied her back to her hotel.
Children under 10 must be accompanied by an adult.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I asked my cousin to accompany me because she knew the way to the temple. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to happen  or exist at the same time as something else
dictionaryExamples: The course books are accompanied by four CDs.
The salmon was accompanied by  a fresh green salad.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was very hot and a shining sun accompanied us during our trip. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to play music to support someone else who is playing or singing
dictionaryExamples: He accompanied me on the piano.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year, for instance, the concert became a recital: two singers performed Lieder by Schubert accompanied by the piano and by the sweet sound of Arimany's golden flute. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to succeed in doing or finishing something
dictionaryExamples: I feel like I didn't accomplish anything today.
She accomplished what she'd set out to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To accomplish this, schools should try to respect the individuality of each child, give them chances to think more freely. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: as said by someone or shown by something
dictionaryExamples: According to Sarah, they're not getting along lately.
According to our records, you owe us $80.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the guide, it was a famous culture in ancient times. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that agrees with
dictionaryExamples: Students are all put in different groups according to their ability.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The job included organizing suitable activities according to their age, capability and wishes. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an arrangement with a bank to keep your money there and to allow you to take it out when you need to
dictionaryExamples: a checking/savings account
I've opened an account at another bank.
I deposited the money in my account this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The man, whose name I can't remember, wrote a serious looking message in which he [talked about] a money transfer to a Swiss bank account. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a written or spoken description of something that has happened
dictionaryExamples: She gave a thrilling account  of her life in the jungle.
The documents provide a detailed account of the town's early history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be very interested [in participating] and [writing] the accounts of our journeys. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to consider something when judging a situation
dictionaryExamples: A good architect takes account of the building's surroundings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you will take account of our request. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to consider something when judging a situation
dictionaryExamples: I think you have to take into account the fact that he's a good deal younger than the rest of us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking into account all these arguments, I also think, like many people, that keeping animals in zoos is cruel and unnecessary. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: because of something
dictionaryExamples: He doesn't eat any dairy products on account of the diet he is following.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On account of its location, it is always busy. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: as said by a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: The party was, by all accounts, a great success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have known Michael Van Cleef for over two decades now, and he is, by all accounts, an exemplary worker. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to be the reason for something, or to explain the reason for something
dictionaryExamples: Can you account for your absence last Friday?
He'd had an argument with Caroline, which accounts for his bad mood this morning.
She was asked to account for the missing money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could not account for what had happened. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to form part of a total amount or number of something
dictionaryExamples: Senior citizens account for more than 25 percent of the state's population.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you look carefully at the attached pie-chart, you will easily see that the administration costs and the cost of entertainment account for a mere 15% of the total amount raised. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: responsible for what you do and having to be able to explain your actions
dictionaryExamples: Hospitals must be held accountable for their mistakes.
Politicians should be accountable to the public that elects them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, there should be a person who should be held accountable and [is] accessible to our complaints. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: someone whose job is to keep or examine the financial records of a person or organization
dictionaryExamples: a tax accountant
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am working as an accountant at Deloitte & Touche. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to increase in amount over a period of time, or to make something increase over a period of time
dictionaryExamples: The chemicals accumulate in your body.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's nothing you can do with [the] waste, and that piled-up litter begins to unpleasantly smell as it accumulates in enormous quantities, but what's worse it can be really dangerous as the weather is really hot. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: an amount of something that has been collected
dictionaryExamples: Despite this accumulation of evidence, the government did nothing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is success? For some it is the accumulation of pos[s]es[s]ions, for others it's fame, health, love. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: how correct or  exact something is
dictionaryExamples: We can predict changes with a surprising degree of accuracy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was very disappointed to observe your lack of accuracy in the description of this wonderful event. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: correct, exact and without any mistakes
dictionaryExamples: accurate information/measurements
She was able to give the police a fairly accurate description of the man.
Her novel is an accurate reflection of life in post-war Spain.
We hope to become more accurate in predicting earthquakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some information in the Guidebook was not very accurate. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in an accurate way
dictionaryExamples: The plans should be drawn as accurately as possible, showing all the measurements.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's necessary to consider a lot of aspects to answer this question accurately, but in general I would prefer to go to work by bicycle. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when you say that someone has done something bad
dictionaryExamples: He made a number of accusations against his former colleagues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have enclosed the Distribution Chart in order to prevent you from [making] further accusations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to say that someone has done something bad
dictionaryExamples: He's been accused of robbery/murder.
Are you accusing me of lying?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were accused of vandalism. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a feeling of pain over an area of your body which continues for a long time
dictionaryExamples: As you get older, you have all sorts of aches and pains.
I've got an  ache in my lower back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since then, I have [had] a[n] ache in my left leg. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to have a continuous pain that is unpleasant but not strong
dictionaryExamples: My head/tooth/back aches.
I ache/I'm aching all over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a[n] hour of horseback riding your muscles can really ache. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to succeed in doing something good, usually by working hard
dictionaryExamples: She finally achieved her goal to visit South America.
The program, he claimed, was achieving its objectives.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father is a person who has achieved a lot of great things in his life. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something very good and difficult that you have succeeded in doing
dictionaryExamples: An Olympic silver medal is a remarkable achievement for such a young athlete.
It gives you a sense of achievement if you actually make it to the end of a very long book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think this is an achievement because he is now a lawyer. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a liquid substance that can react chemically with and sometimes dissolve other materials
dictionaryExamples: hydrochloric/fatty acid
Vinegar is an acid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We saw a little black dragon with scales like iron charging [at] us and spitting acid. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to send in the application form soon, so if you can give me some advice, it would be great! Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: to make a suggestion about what you think someone should do or how they should do something
dictionaryExamples: I think I'd advise him to leave the company.
I'd strongly advise against making a sudden decision.
They're advising that children be kept out of the sun altogether.
I'd advise waiting until tomorrow.
She advised us when to come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I advise you to go there and have a good time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: someone whose job is to give advice about a subject
dictionaryExamples: a financial adviser
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of our financial advisers could provide your students [with] the latest methods used in Accounting and in developing new business projects. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to express support for a particular idea or way of doing things
dictionaryExamples: I certainly wouldn't advocate the use of violence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just like Mahatma Gandhi, who advocated non-violent methods of struggle, Picasso struggled against fascism [by] peaceful means, namely with his art. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who supports a particular idea or way of doing things
dictionaryExamples: He has always been an advocate of space exploration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Advocates of international tourism subscribe to the view that mass tourism offer[s] benefits to the whole community. International English Language Testing System; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a situation, matter, or set of related events that is being dealt with or considered
dictionaryExamples: The meeting was addressed by an expert in South American affairs.
What I do in my spare time is my own affair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make matters worse, people gossiped about me and tried to find out more and more about my private affairs, which made me feel embarrassed. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a sexual relationship, especially a secret one
dictionaryExamples: Do you think he's having an affair with someone?
The book is the story of a long love affair that has a sad ending.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am that kind of indivi[dua]l that loves stories, they can be either love affairs or fantastic adventures but I really enjoy getting involved in some kind of story. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to have an influence on someone or something, or to cause them to change
dictionaryExamples: The divorce affected every aspect of her life.
Both buildings were badly affected by the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The telephone is a very important invention, which has affected our lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to cause a strong emotion, especially sadness
dictionaryExamples: I was deeply affected by the film.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the fo[u]rth song, 'Rebel[l]ion' started, I was deeply affected by the r[h]ythm. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling of liking or loving a person or place
dictionaryExamples: He had a  deep affection for his aunt.
She felt no affection for the child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition she loves me very much and she offers a lot of affection to me when I face a difficult situation with my job. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: showing that you like or love someone
dictionaryExamples: an affectionate child
He's very affectionate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is attentive and affectionate, but most of all she is a sweet mother. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: having a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: affluent suburbs/neighborhoods/families
It's an affluent residential suburb just north of the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children who come from poor families are more mature and responsible than those children coming from affluent families. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: cheap enough for most people to be able to buy
dictionaryExamples: We need more affordable housing in this area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are very pleased with the affordable fares, however they are more inclined to comfort. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when a time or event has happened
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to go for a walk after breakfast?
We had a chat after the meeting.
Let's get the shopping done. After that, we can stop for coffee.
After a while, I began to like him.
His birthday is exactly a week after mine.
It was so boring, I left after ten minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go shopping, eat [a tasty] meal and after that you can go to the disco and dance all night. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: when you have gone past a particular place
dictionaryExamples: Turn left after the hotel.
You want the turn on the right just after the police station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go to a wonderful place near here, The Great Falls. This is a very good place because you can [do] extreme sports. It is just after the town, on Main Road. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: following in order
dictionaryExamples: H comes after G in the alphabet.

sense.def: following someone or something
dictionaryExamples: We ran after him but he got away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ran after the bus and shouted to her 'hurry up!' Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true
dictionaryExamples: You can't expect to be perfect - after all, it was only your first lesson.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stopped talking with my friends, but not [for long] -  after all, we are friends. Anyway, I'm planning nice things for the next April 1st. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: day after day/year after year, etc.

sense.def: happening every day/year, etc. over a long period
dictionaryExamples: We rented the same house in Maine for our vacation year after year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And there she was, day after day, walking in the rain... Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: because of something that happened
dictionaryExamples: I'll never trust her again after what she did to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really needed those days after what I've been through this spring. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: despite
dictionaryExamples: I can't believe he was so rude to you after all the help you've given him!
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: But, even after earning more in 2001, the women still do not earn as much [as] men on average earned (£20,363) in 1997. 
 International English Language Testing System; C1; Gujarati

sense.def: used to say that something happened or was true although you did not expect it to happen or be true
dictionaryExamples: Helen couldn't come to the party after all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cars still enter the city so there will be pollution after all. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: used when giving someone or something the same name as another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: She’s named after her aunt.
It was called the Biko building, after the famous South African.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I called her Lena after my sister. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: later than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Hilary got here at noon and Nicholas arrived soon after.
I can't go next week - how about the week after?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Joe, I would love to see the film with you. We must have dinner after. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: at a later time than something else happens
dictionaryExamples: Soon/shortly after we got on the highway, the car started to make a strange noise.
I went to the post office right after I left you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope we will meet soon after I come back home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: the time between the middle of the day and the evening
dictionaryExamples: It was a sunny afternoon.
She works three afternoons a week at the library.
Let's go to the park this afternoon.
She's coming by on Wednesday afternoon.
He's been in a bad mood all afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She cooks every afternoon. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: at a later time, after something else has happened
dictionaryExamples: We had lunch, and afterward we sat on the deck and watched the kids play in the pool.
They separated, and soon/shortly afterward Jane left the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that we have a Disco[,] and Buffet of food afterward. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: once more
dictionaryExamples: Could you spell your name again, please?
Throw it away and start again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you again. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: as before
dictionaryExamples: Get some rest and you'll soon be well again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, it started to rain when we were leaving the town, but five minutes later the weather became warm again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: many times
dictionaryExamples: He played the same song again and again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read it again and again and was more and more surprised. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: again
dictionaryExamples: Once again I'm left with all the dirty dishes!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once again I'm sorry. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: repeated from the beginning
dictionaryExamples: We had to start all over again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: again after something has happened or been done many times before
dictionaryExamples: The bus was late yet again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tom, thank you so much yet again for your interest, this talk is very important to me and to count on you is an honour for our college. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used when adding a fact to something you have just said
dictionaryExamples: I failed my history test - but then again, I didn't do much studying for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact that people live longer nowadays does have some advantages, but then again it also causes a lot of problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: competing with or opposing someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Germany are playing against Brazil in the final tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it very much because I can play it [o]n the Internet with all of my friends and I can also form a team to play against other teams in tournaments. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: next to and touching something
dictionaryExamples: Why don't we put the bed against the wall?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On your left there is a large window and on the right there is a desk between the two cupboards, they are against the wall. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: in the opposite direction to
dictionaryExamples: Commuting is not so bad when you are traveling against the traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had to fight against the wind and the rain. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: disagreeing with a plan or activity
dictionaryExamples: She spoke against the decision to close the school.
Are you for or against the proposal?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I intend to examine the facts for and against this problem. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: forbidden by a law
dictionaryExamples: It's against the law to leave a young child alone in the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Until that moment, Mary thought [he]r uncle and his friends were smugglers and were doing things against the law. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to have a reason not to like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Ellen doesn't have anything against bowling either, so let's go!
I have nothing against him personally, I just don't think he's the right man for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have nothing against taking public transport, I suggest taking a bus. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If you do something against someone's advice, wishes, etc., you do it although they have said you should not or must not.
dictionaryExamples: He flew there against his doctor's advice.
She sold the house even though it was against his wishes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a very ambitious student who wasn't afraid to develop ideas in unconventional ways and pursue his research even against the advice of his supervisors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If you do or achieve something against all the odds, you succeed although you were not likely to.
dictionaryExamples: We won the game against all odds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The stormy waters and heavy winds were a great challenge, and almost deemed it impossible for me to succeed, but against all odds I managed to defeat my fears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the number of years that someone has lived, or that something has existed
dictionaryExamples: I'd guess she's about my age.
We're the same age.
She was 74 years of age when she wrote her first novel.
He left home at the age of 16.
The show appeals to people of all ages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is the same age as me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: a particular period of history
dictionaryExamples: the modern/information age
the ice age
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can begin by visiting its castle, which goes back to the middle ages.  First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the state of being old or becoming old
dictionaryExamples: He is starting to show his age.
The value of the painting has increased with age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually, as the saying goes, we grow wiser with age. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrase: at the tender age of 8/17/25, etc.

sense.def: at the young age of 8/17/25, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She first appeared on stage at the tender age of 12.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She met my father at the tender age of 14, and she soon knew that this was the man she wanted to stay with for the rest of her life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: of the age of
dictionaryExamples: They've got one daughter, Isabel, aged 3.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a club for pupils aged between twelve and eighteen. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a business that provides a service
dictionaryExamples: an advertising/employment/real estate/travel agency
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I am employed in a travel agency and last week I started my new English class. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: an international or government organization
dictionaryExamples: the Environmental Protection Agency
government/federal/local/international agencies
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Television conveys the weather forecasts and any warnings issued by the government agencies, such as flood alerts. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tamil

sense.def: a list of subjects that people will discuss at a meeting
dictionaryExamples: There are several items on the agenda.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your memo was one of the points on the agenda for last week's meeting. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: important subjects that have to be dealt with
dictionaryExamples: Finding a job is at the top of my agenda.
Quality of life issues are high on the city council's agenda.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, the Temple de la Sagrada Familia was at the top of my agenda, but I could never imagine its beauty and its gigantic size by which I was really taken aback. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone whose job is to deal with business for someone else
dictionaryExamples: Please contact our agent in Spain for further information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope the agent will sell it soon. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: someone who tries to find out secret information, especially about another country
dictionaryExamples: a secret agent
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She interrupted and told the man that she was a secret agent. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a very long time
dictionaryExamples: I've been waiting here for ages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel like I've been here for ages. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: angry or violent behavior toward someone
dictionaryExamples: an act of aggression
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it can turn into [a] terrible form of violence and aggression, where the very sense of competition is forgotten and only wild instincts prevail. International English Language Testing System; C1; Turkish

sense.def: behaving in an angry and violent way toward another person
dictionaryExamples: aggressive behavior
If I criticize him, he gets aggressive and starts shouting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At such moments he became angry and aggressive. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: using forceful methods and determined to succeed
dictionaryExamples: The company mounted an aggressive marketing campaign.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our competitors pursue a more aggressive marketing strategy, despite the fact [that] they offer inferior products. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: in an aggressive way
dictionaryExamples: Small children often behave aggressively.
They played more aggressively in the second half.

sense.def: used to refer to a time in the past
dictionaryExamples: He left the house over an hour ago.
We left New York ten years ago.
About five months ago, I got a letter from him.
The dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two months ago I booked a trip to Malta. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Russian

sense.def: If something happened long ago, it happened a great amount of time ago.
dictionaryExamples: I think we met once, long ago.
It was not long ago that I last saw him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not so long ago, you could ring each Dutch doorbell of your choice at 6 pm and you'd f[i]nd the whole family gathered around the kitchen table, having their supper. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to have the same opinion as someone
dictionaryExamples: I agree with you.
My father and I don't agree about/on very much.
We all agreed that mistakes had been made.
"You're absolutely right," agreed Jake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you agree with me? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to decide something with someone
dictionaryExamples: We agreed to meet on Sunday.
We couldn't agree on what to buy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were not so sure which film we wanted to see but we agreed to see "Blade 3" at seven o'clock. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: to say you will do something that someone asks you to
dictionaryExamples: She agreed to help him.
The bank has agreed to lend me $5000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came home, I told my mother everything and she agreed to put him up. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If two descriptions, statements, etc., agree, they are the same.
dictionaryExamples: Her notes do not agree with what I remember happening.
Does the information in  the two reports agree?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This does not agree with the intentions of our Program. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to think that something is correct or acceptable
dictionaryExamples: I don't agree with hunting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't agree with keeping animals in zoos; I think that it's cruel and unnecessary. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a promise or decision made between two or more groups or people
dictionaryExamples: an agreement with the company
an agreement between both parties
It was difficult to reach an agreement.
The president has signed an international  agreement on climate change.

They have broken 
                      the agreement on human rights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was an attempt to cut down on using and producing sprays which destroy the ozon[e] layer [and] an international agreement was signed. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when people have the same opinion or make the same decision
dictionaryExamples: Are we all in agreement?
There was broad agreement about/on what to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The decision of not taking that tour has already been made by general agreement. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: farming
dictionaryExamples: Agriculture is still largely based on traditional methods in some countries.
The area depends on agriculture for most of its income.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who live in big cities suffer from air pollu[t]ion and noise, and vill[a]gers suffer from chemicals us[ed] for agriculture. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in front
dictionaryExamples: Turn left at the traffic light, and you'll see the hospital straight ahead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Behind our school there was a beautiful forest and if you walked 200 meters straight ahead you would reach a clearing. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: in the future
dictionaryExamples: She has a difficult time ahead of her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even if you're satisfied with your life now, take a look 10 or 20 years ahead. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: having more points than someone else in a competition
dictionaryExamples: Barcelona was ahead after ten minutes.

sense.def: before the time that was planned
dictionaryExamples: We finished the project ahead of schedule.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, a bonus will be given if the project finishes ahead of schedule. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: making more progress than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Sue is ahead of everyone else in French.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have always been a couple of steps ahead of my schoolmates and peers, not only in terms of scholastic pursuits, but in my opinions and desires as well. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: help or support
dictionaryExamples: She went to the aid of a man trapped in his car.
He applied for financial aid for college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have any trouble with something do not hesitate [i]n requesting my aid. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: money, food, or equipment that is given to help a country or group of people
dictionaryExamples: Emergency aid was sent to the flood victims.
foreign aid
aid workers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another thing which they say is that in the past they gave aid to poorer countries for different projects. International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi

sense.def: using something to help you
dictionaryExamples: She walks with the aid of a cane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The newest computer can handle data that human brains cannot and therefore all scientific research [is] carried out with the aid of computers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a piece of equipment that helps you to do something
dictionaryExamples: teaching aids such as books and videos
A good dictionary can be a useful aid to understanding a new language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In particular, the magazine could be considered as a rather good additional aid for someone studying the Greek language and culture. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to help someone
dictionaryExamples: The project is designed to aid the homeless.
He was aided in his research by his knowledge of Greek.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This kind of bad publicity will not aid the hospital in any way, but will instead keep people away from future events. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: the purpose of doing something, and what you hope to achieve
dictionaryExamples: He went to Paris with the aim of improving his French.
My main aim is to make people laugh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim was to get a picture of each person. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to intend to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: I aim to be a millionaire by the time I'm 35.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our English Club aims to help students with their English. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to be intended to influence or affect a particular person or group
dictionaryExamples: These advertisements are specifically aimed at young people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: PIAZZA is too modern and is aimed at the young. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to be intended to achieve a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: a plan aimed at reducing traffic
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working within projects aimed at improving local agricultural output, I stayed 3 years in South America. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: travel in an aircraft
dictionaryExamples: I don't travel much by air.
air travel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [will] travel there by air. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
dictionaryExamples: I went outside to get some fresh air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of different kinds of animals, lakes, fresh air and trees. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the space above and around things
dictionaryExamples: He kicked the ball high in the air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was an old painting. In it, a man was holding his axe up in the air and was ready to hit a tree. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: played on television or radio
dictionaryExamples: His show is on the air from 11:00 to 11:30 Monday through Thursday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you can see, it’s probably the first chance to learn good English on T.V. Another surprising thing is that it's not on the air too late, so you can watch it without oversleeping in the morning. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a particular appearance or quality
dictionaryExamples: He has an air of confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The service is excellent and the atmosphere is quite nice, with an air of elegance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to get rid of bad feelings between two people or groups
dictionaryExamples: We had a big argument, but I think it helped clear the air.
The meeting Friday will help clear the air and clarify some issues that need to be addressed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I rushed into the room [to] cheer them up and clear the air, although I knew it was too late. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to suddenly disappear in a mysterious way
dictionaryExamples: He was on the path ahead of me and then vanished into thin air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sitting on a couch and squeezed between my elderly aunts, I sincerely wished I could vanish into thin air. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: someone or something that is new, different, and exciting
dictionaryExamples: Having Eve around has been a breath of fresh air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should this be everything the Town Council has promised, it will bring a breath of fresh air for our local youth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the system used for keeping the air in a building or vehicle cool
dictionaryExamples: I wish my car had air conditioning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rooms are big and there['s] cable TV and air conditioning. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: any vehicle, with or without an engine, which can fly, such as a plane or helicopter
dictionaryExamples: military/commercial aircraft
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They have all [the] Swedish aircraft that have ever be[en] buil[t]. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the part of a country's military organization that uses aircraft to fight wars
dictionaryExamples: an air force pilot
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the day you can visit all of our museums or schools or even the air force base, which is open from 9[:]00 until [6:]00. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a company that provides regular flights to places
dictionaryExamples: What airline did you fly?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She explained the situation to the authorities and because there was no flight back to London, the airline had no choice but to pay [for] her stay. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a vehicle that flies and has at least one engine and wings
dictionaryExamples: She has her own private airplane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will travel by airplane and I will arrive at half past three. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a place where aircraft regularly take off and land, with buildings for passengers to wait in
dictionaryExamples: an international airport
O'Hare Airport in Chicago
an airport terminal/runway
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lake is not far from the airport. Key English Test; A2; Hungarian

sense.def: a loud noise or flashing light that warns you of danger
dictionaryExamples: a burglar/car/fire/smoke alarm
What set off the alarm?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It turned out that the fire alarm had gone off and they had to evacuate the building. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a clock or a device in a watch, cell phone, etc. that makes a noise to wake you
dictionaryExamples: The alarm went off at 5:30 and she got up immediately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly the alarm started to ring and I woke up to go to school. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a sudden feeling of fear or worry that something bad might happen
dictionaryExamples: There's no need for alarm - everything is fine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately, her soothing voice damped down any sense of alarm. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone worried or frightened
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to alarm you but he really should be here by now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What alarmed us the most was the daring use of speculation by the author. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a clock that you can set to wake you up at a particular time with a loud noise
dictionaryExamples: My  alarm clock went off at 5:00.
I've set the alarm clock for 7:30.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave me an alarm clock so I won't be late [for] school any more. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: causing worry or fear
dictionaryExamples: alarming news
Family owned farms have been disappearing at an alarming rate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, the alarming frequency of heart attacks in Poland [has] made people stop eating too much fat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: although
dictionaryExamples: He tried, albeit without success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If and when homework, household chores and social duties had been dealt with, we were free to pursue our own designs, albeit usually hampered by a younger child tagging along. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a book in which you keep photographs, stamps, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We looked through his photo albums together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave me a photo album. Key English Test; A2; Ukrainian

sense.def: several songs or pieces of music on a CD, a record, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They've just make/recorded a new album.
Jovanotti has a new album out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a CD-player and a new album [by] U2 and a new book by Jeanette Winterson. Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: drinks such as wine and beer which can make you drunk
dictionaryExamples: Most wines contain between 10% and 15% alcohol.
an alcohol-free beer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party was excellent. We danced, ate, drank alcohol and... Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: containing alcohol
dictionaryExamples: alcoholic beverages
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm only 15 years old and not allowed to drink alcoholic drinks. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: regularly drinking too much alcohol and unable to stop the habit
dictionaryExamples: an alcoholic friend/brother

sense.def: someone who regularly drinks too much alcohol and cannot stop the habit
dictionaryExamples: He became an alcoholic when his wife left him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The quality of the orchestra was poor - it only consisted of amateurs - and the conductor was drunk - he was an alcoholic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: quick to notice and react to things around you
dictionaryExamples: A young dog should be alert and playful.
Teachers need to be alert to sudden changes in students' behavior.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A little bit of tension is alright - I guess it keeps you alert while driving. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to warn someone of a possibly dangerous situation
dictionaryExamples: The auto manufacturer alerted owners to a problem with the  window and asked that they bring the car in to be checked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Karl Marx alerted us all to the fact that work can cause alienation, and that repetitive tasks, or tasks which do not involve a great deal of interaction with other human beings, can make us feel estranged. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a warning about a possibly dangerous situation
dictionaryExamples: a traffic alert
A severe weather alert for this area is in effect until 6 pm.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Moreover, the Television conveys the most needed day-to-day weather forecasts and any warnings issued by the government agencies, such as flood alerts. 
 International English Language Testing System; C1; Tamil

sense.def: similar
dictionaryExamples: The children all look very alike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, Jem and Joss Merlyn look alike physically. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: in a similar way
dictionaryExamples: We think alike.
My father treated us all alike.

sense.def: used after referring to two groups of people or things to show that both groups are included
dictionaryExamples: Friends and family alike were shocked by the news of her death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was indeed a great treat for old and young alike. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to continue to live or exist and be full of energy, or to be popular or successful
dictionaryExamples: Jennifer is alive and well and living in New Zealand.

Traditional jazz is still alive and well 
                   in Chicago.

sense.def: full of activity and excitement
dictionaryExamples: The park was alive with the sound of laughter.
The city comes alive at night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Normally you would pass by without noticing it, but once a year Roskilde comes alive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: continuing to exist
dictionaryExamples: Local people are fighting to keep the language alive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thirdly, it keeps the village alive, since many people from other villages come to celebrate with them, and our national heritage (traditional songs, dances, costumes) is kept alive too. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: every person or thing in a group
dictionaryExamples: I've seen all of his movies.
All of us had left by midnight.
She's got four children, all under the age of five.
"Which of his books did you like best?" "I loved them all."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you are all well. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish

sense.def: the whole of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I've been studying all day.
It rained all week.
I've been waiting all afternoon for him to call.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I spent all day [at the] beach. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: the whole amount of something
dictionaryExamples: I've spent all my money.

By morning, all the snow had gone.

sense.def: many different types of something
dictionaryExamples: They had all sorts of jewelry for sale.
We saw all sorts  of animals in the park.

sense.def: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionaryExamples: Well, all the best - it was nice meeting you.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to wish you all the best! Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: continuously
dictionaryExamples: I wish you'd stop criticizing me all the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He laugh[s] all the time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the only thing

sense.def: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type

dictionaryExamples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.

sense.def: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true

sense.def: everything is in a good or acceptable state

sense.def: used for saying that other similar things are included or that the whole of a situation is considered

sense.def: used to show the total amount of something
dictionaryExamples: Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.

sense.def: suddenly
dictionaryExamples: All of a sudden, he came running in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All of a sudden, a weird creature popped into his dream. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: repeated from the beginning
dictionaryExamples: We had to start all over again.

dictionaryExamples: Helen couldn't come to the party after all.

sense.def: very late at night, until early morning, or almost all the time
dictionaryExamples: Our neighbors play loud music at all hours of the day and night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This causes traffic jams at all hours of the day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: suddenly
dictionaryExamples: All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All at once, everything started to work again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: used for saying that something is true in general if you think about all its aspects
dictionaryExamples: The show was a great success, all things considered.

sense.def: despite
dictionaryExamples: For all her qualifications, she's useless at the job.

sense.def: completely or very
dictionaryExamples: The cake was all eaten last night.
You're all wet!
Tell me all about your trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to tell you all about it. Key English Test; A2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: in every place
dictionaryExamples: He's traveled all over the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The people in the class are from all over the world. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: from the beginning of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I knew all along that it was a mistake.

sense.def: considering everything
dictionaryExamples: All in all, it was a great vacation.

sense.def: in or to many different places

sense.def: used to show that you do not agree with something or that you are annoyed about something

sense.def: to be ready
dictionaryExamples: We were all set to go when the phone rang.

sense.def: much better, easier, more exciting, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The journey was all the more dangerous because of the bad weather.

sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In contrast to your allegations, our study shows that a vast majority (78%) use Greendale Park for recreation as often as once a week. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: believed to be true, but not proved

dictionaryExamples: Someone at the company allegedly had lost the records.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Nevertheless, nowadays, people allegedly live longer than they did in the past. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an agreement between people, countries, political parties, etc., to work together to achieve something

an alliance between the countries/families/groups

sense.def: joined by a formal agreement
dictionaryExamples: the allied powers

sense.def: a part of the money, time, space, etc., which can be used for a particular purpose

sense.def: to plan to use a particular amount of money, time, etc., for something

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's all right. Don't worry about [it].Key English Test; A2; Thai

dictionaryExamples: I almost missed the bus.
She's almost thirty.
It was almost six o'clock when he left.

The boat sank almost immediately when it hit the rock.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Did you know that almost the whole class came to my party? Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: without other people
dictionaryExamples: He likes being alone in the house.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She doesn't want to go alone. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: from one part of a road, river, etc. to another
dictionaryExamples: a romantic walk along the beach/river
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last night, we walked along the Thames. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: in a line next to or beside something long

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]he Norwich river is wonderful and I enjoyed myself seeing all [the] white houses with their gardens along it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: based on and similar to something
dictionaryExamples: He gave a talk along the lines of the one he gave in Oxford.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Imagine one is encouraged by friends and institutions for their 'different' artistic or other activities, even if their works are not along the lines of 'acceptable' norms and tradition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: moving forward
dictionaryExamples: We were just walking along, chatting.

sense.def: with you
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you take him along with you when you go?
I'll bring some food along and we can have a picnic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My boyfriend came along with me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at a particular place on a road, river, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Somewhere along this road there's a garage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She told me [that] along the road there are several places to visit, like a castle which is open [to the] public. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: from the beginning of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I knew all along that it was a mistake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the future the key word for fashion will be comfort as this is basically what everyone has been wanting all along. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: in addition to someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Now we’ve got hospital bills along with our usual expenses.

sense.def: next to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: A car pulled up alongside ours.
