sense.def: together with someone
dictionaryExamples: She enjoyed working alongside such famous actors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also he worked alongside me at another travel agency for 6 months. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: in a way that other people can hear
dictionaryExamples: He read her letter aloud to the rest of the family.
I laughed aloud at some of his comments.
I was just thinking aloud.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thinking aloud is an old habit of mine. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a set of letters arranged in a fixed order which is used for writing a language
dictionaryExamples: the Cyrillic alphabet
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They should learn the normal alphabet and handwriting because it is more friendly to write a letter to a friend. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: arranged in the same order as the letters of the alphabet
dictionaryExamples: an alphabetical list
The names are published in alphabetical order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked again at the strange words and then she understood. Each letter ha[d] been replaced by the next one in the alphabetical order. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: before now, or before a particular time in the past

sense.def: in addition

sense.def: to change, or to make someone or something change

sense.def: An alternative plan, method, etc. is one that you can use if you do not want to use another one.

an alternative lifestyle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder if you've ever heard of "alternative music"? First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

dictionaryExamples: We could go to the Indian restaurant, or alternatively, we could try that new Italian place.

dictionaryExamples: She walked home by herself, although she knew that it was dangerous.

sense.def: in total

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: She wrote less and less often, and eventually she stopped altogether.
I'm not altogether sure about the idea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't altogether agree with this fact. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you consider everything
dictionaryExamples: Altogether, I'd say the party was a great success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Altogether, I believe that the most cruel creature on earth is the human being. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a light, silver-colored metal used for making containers, cooking equipment and aircraft parts
dictionaryExamples: Cover the fish with aluminum foil and bake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people think that associations like Greenpeace can do something, they also try to recycle old things like batteries, aluminum, bottles or to forbid some drivers to go with their car in some area[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: every time, or at all times
dictionaryExamples: I always walk to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always tr[y] to do [my] best, bec[a]use I want to be a good student. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: at all times in the past
dictionaryExamples: We've always lived here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always wanted a phone with mp3 and bluetooth. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: forever
dictionaryExamples: I'll always remember you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was the best weekend [of] my life. I'll always remember it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian

sense.def: used to suggest something
dictionaryExamples: You can always stay with us if you miss your train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Watching them painting is better than seeing their art in any museum, and you can always do some sightseeing through our historical ruins, our mountains or villages. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: again and again, often in an annoying way
dictionaryExamples: He's always losing his keys.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am always trying to convince my friend Maria of these dangers. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a time between twelve o'clock at night and twelve o'clock in the middle of the day
dictionaryExamples: We're open between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. daily.
The first election results are expected around 1 a.m.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class start[s] at 10:00 a.m. and it finish[s] at 11:00 a.m. It's one hour. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: doing something as a hobby and not as your job
dictionaryExamples: an amateur photographer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally I would like to mention that I feel very confident in front of cameras, since I am an amateur actor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone who does something as a hobby and not as their job
dictionaryExamples: This tennis tournament is open to both amateurs and professionals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I want to explain is that if an amateur sees a professional swimmer winning while wearing our equipment, he is surely going to think that our products helped him succeed, so the amateur is going to buy our equipment too. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone who is not good at what they do
dictionaryExamples: I won't be giving them any more work - they're a bunch of amateurs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I admit that I was an amateur, [which] is why I did not try to do any special "tricks" to impress all those who were watching me. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: extremely surprised
dictionaryExamples: She was amazed at how calm she felt after the accident.
I was absolutely amazed when I heard the news.
I was amazed to hear that Chris had won first prize.
I'm amazed (that) she didn't complain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear David Beckham, How are you? I was amazed to find your letter in my mail box. Preliminary English Test; B1; Gujarati

sense.def: extreme surprise
dictionaryExamples: She stared in amazement.
To my amazement, he ate the whole thing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, to her amazement, she saw him with another girl. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: very good or impressive in some way
dictionaryExamples: This wine is really amazing.
What an amazing meal!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I b[o]u[ght] a new cell phone [and] it is amazing. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: extremely surprising
dictionaryExamples: It's amazing to think that the managing director is only 23.
It's amazing that no one else has applied for the job.
The amazing thing is that it was kept secret for so long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Richard, It's amazing you didn't forget my birthday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in an amazing way
dictionaryExamples: The food was amazingly good.
Amazingly enough, no one else has applied for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Amazingly, he didn't come back until midnight. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: the main official sent by a government of a country to represent it in another country
dictionaryExamples: Britain's ambassador in Moscow has refused to comment.
She's a former ambassador to the United States.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the first floor [is] the "star'' of the museum: a splendid grand piano built in 1893, which was offered by the Queen to the French ambassador in 1895. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when something has more than one possible meaning
dictionaryExamples: Legal documents must be free of ambiguity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lastly, there is the ambiguity of her final decision. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: having more than one possible meaning
dictionaryExamples: an ambiguous statement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is hard to choose the right option as the advice given [often] seems ambiguous. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Czech

sense.def: something you want to achieve
dictionaryExamples: His ambition is to run his own business.
He has already achieved his main ambition in life - to become wealthy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Learning English is one of my ambition[s]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a strong feeling that you want to be successful or powerful
dictionaryExamples: My sister always had more ambition than I did.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Love, hate, ambition and fear [of] losing are the main subjects for Orson Well[e]s and Tim Burton, the directors [of these two films]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: wanting  to be successful or powerful
dictionaryExamples: an ambitious young lawyer
He's very ambitious for his children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I chose Omar because I find him very talented and ambitious. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

sense.def: If a plan or idea is ambitious, it will need a lot of work and will be difficult to achieve.
dictionaryExamples: This is our most ambitious project so far.
She has some ambitious plans for her business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we a[c]complish these ambitious plans, we can even run for the 2006 Winter Olympic Games. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a special vehicle used to take ill or injured people to the hospital
dictionaryExamples: I called for an ambulance.
an ambulance driver
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She called for an ambulance which came at once. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to slightly change the words of a document
dictionaryExamples: The contract has now been amended.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The text could be amended. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a change in the words of a document, or the process of doing this
dictionaryExamples: to make an amendment to the human rights law
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its really unfa[i]r  o[f] him as there should be some amendments in this law for people who are physically challenged. International English Language Testing System; C1; Marathi

sense.def: while something else is happening
dictionaryExamples: Security was increased amid fears of further terrorist attacks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are involved so much with their occupation that they will respond to an emergency call even when they are amid sweet dreams or having a joyful time with their love[d] ones. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: among
dictionaryExamples: a village set amid rolling hills
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we are mere fading stars [i]n a huge sky, unsubjected to the elapse of time and instead of following the ancient saying "carpe diem", we get lost amid other stars. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: in the middle of something
dictionaryExamples: I saw a few familiar faces among the crowd.
Rescue teams searched among the ruins for survivors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you love nature, you can eat under trees and among flowers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in a particular group of people or things
dictionaryExamples: Discuss it among yourselves for a few minutes.
Relax -  you're among friends.
She has worked as a real estate agent among other things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have got beautiful presents - some clothes [and] a clock, among other things. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that there are other details or examples in addition to the ones you are mentioning
dictionaryExamples: It's worth visiting the museum while you're here. There's an exhibition about Darwin and a good collection of paintings, among other things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To go by tram or bus is a waste of time and traveling by car is - among other things - a waste of money. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: one of the most extreme examples of a particular type
dictionaryExamples: He is among the top five tennis players in the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was among the worst zoos I have ever seen. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to each one in a group
dictionaryExamples: She divided the cake among the children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although Brazil is the eighth biggest economy in the world and one of the richest countries regarding natural resources, that wealth is not shared equally among the population. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: how much there is of something
dictionaryExamples: They didn't deliver the right amount of sand.
Small amounts of land were used for keeping animals.
I didn't expect the bill to come to this amount.
You wouldn't believe the amount of trouble I've had with this car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll also be able to go out to pubs or night clubs, and you'll spend a very small amount of money. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: enough, or more than enough
dictionaryExamples: She's had ample time to get the work done.

sense.def: to make someone laugh or smile
dictionaryExamples: The video clips on that website always amuse me.
I think it amuses him to see people make fools of themselves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "The Blind Owl" - his masterpiece - is a surrealistic novella which has amused critics and ordinary readers for years. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: to keep someone interested and help them to have an enjoyable time
dictionaryExamples: I bought a book of crosswords to amuse myself while I was on the train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another idea is to call a well-known band to amuse all the young people. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: showing that you think something is funny
dictionaryExamples: an amused smile
She was very amused by/at your comments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the taxi arrived, he was so amused about the news tha[t] an old woman took it. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to keep someone interested and help them to have an enjoyable time
dictionaryExamples: How do you keep an 8-year-old boy amused?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could keep them amused with my funny stories. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the feeling that you have when something makes you smile or laugh
dictionaryExamples: She looked at him with great amusement.
Carl came last in the race, much to my amusement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Each ma[de] the other one laugh. We had great fun. [It was] a day with so much amusement, with my best friend John. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an enjoyable way of spending your time
dictionaryExamples: I play the piano, but just for my own amusement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In particular, computer games are a kind of amusement, for them and for everyone. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: funny or entertaining
dictionaryExamples: an amusing story/person/situation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our teacher is really amusing, [he] makes people laugh all the time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used instead of "a" when the following word begins with a vowel sound
dictionaryExamples: an easy question
an interesting story
an orange
an honest person
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is an au pair in England. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: similar in some ways
dictionaryExamples: The stock market recorded a 0.4% annual increase that was roughly analogous to results in the late 1960s.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Raising the price of petroleum will be analogous to providing hurdles for better communication and thus the progress. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: a comparison that shows how two things are similar
dictionaryExamples: He  used the analogy of the mind, which has no form and is invisible, being like the sky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The analogy bears striking similarities to the relationship of dependency between humans and their construct, the machines. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: the process of analyzing something
dictionaryExamples: Chemical analysis revealed a high content of copper.
I was interested in Clare's analysis of  the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would not do my school projects without using a computer, because I have to do some statistical analysis. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone whose job is to study or examine something in detail
dictionaryExamples: a financial/political/systems analyst
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I got promotion as a project analyst recently. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: examining the details of something carefully, in order to understand or explain it
dictionaryExamples: analytical skills
an analytical mind
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, employers nowadays are seeking the team-working, problem-solving and analytical skills [needed] for their company. International English Language Testing System; C1; Burmese

sense.def: to examine the details of something carefully, in order to understand or explain it
dictionaryExamples: Researchers analyzed purchases made by 6300 households.
Water samples taken from streams were analyzed for chemical contaminants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Almost all the companies use computers in order to collect and to analyze data about their activities or their customers. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a relative who lived a long time ago
dictionaryExamples: My ancestors came from Ireland.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are living in a technologically advanced world where we are surrounded by all sorts of devices, which would seem fantastic to our ancestors. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a heavy, metal object that is dropped into water to stop a boat from moving
dictionaryExamples: We dropped anchor in a quiet bay and swam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Meanwhile, the captain had set the anchor. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone or something that gives support when needed
dictionaryExamples: She was my anchor when things were difficult for me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yet she had still been fond of his picture, he was her anchor. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the person who reports the news and manages reports by others on a television or radio program
dictionaryExamples: She was interviewed by the anchor of the CBS Evening News.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This new form of expression is already shaping our lives, as recently seen in the U.S., where a major news anchor was fined due to findings published in a blog. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop a boat from moving by dropping a heavy metal object into the water
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every night we used to anchor [i]n different bays to spend the night. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to make something or someone stay in one position by fastening them firmly
dictionaryExamples: We anchored ourselves to the rocks with a rope.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was stronger, much more intense than text or video footage could ever be, for this unmoving image, having been anchored in space and time, solidified its content so as to have an almost physical impact on the viewer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: from a long time ago
dictionaryExamples: ancient Greece/Rome/Egypt
ancient monuments/ruins
People have lived in this valley since ancient times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would recommend you to visit Rome, because you shouldn't miss [seeing] the huge monuments, the ancient Roman ruins and the Vatican. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to join two words, phrases, parts of sentences or related statements together
dictionaryExamples: Ann and Jim
knives and forks
We kissed and hugged each other.
Straighten up your room. And don't forget to make your bed!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have got [a] nice bed, [a] mirror, [a] sofa and a table. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: used to say that one thing happens after another thing
dictionaryExamples: I got dressed and had my breakfast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I get up early [in the] morning and I have breakfast. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: used when saying or adding numbers
dictionaryExamples: It cost a hundred and twenty dollars.
Two and three equals five.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's about two and a half hours. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: used instead of "to" after some verbs, such as "try" and "go"

I asked him to go and find my glasses.
Wait and  see  what happens.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope [to] go and see Disneyland. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: together with other similar things
dictionaryExamples: schools, colleges and so on

sense.def: used between two words which are the same to make their meaning stronger
dictionaryExamples: She spends hours and hours on the telephone.
The sound grew louder and louder.
We laughed and laughed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The situation became harder and harder. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a spiritual creature in stories or some religions, usually represented as a human with wings
dictionaryExamples: According to the Bible, an angel told Mary that she would have God's son, Jesus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to wear a top with a picture of an angel that my mother bought for me as my birthday present. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: a strong feeling against someone who has behaved badly, making you want to shout at them or hurt them
dictionaryExamples: I think he feels a lot of anger towards his father who treated him very badly as a child.
The people showed no surprise or anger at their treatment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Trisha, who had invited us there, looked like she was about to explode with anger or burst into tears. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the space between two lines or surfaces at the point at which they touch each other, measured in degrees
dictionaryExamples: an angle of 90 degrees
The interior angles of a square are right angles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Carriers are to be requested to stick to the regulations which set the approach and takeoff angles at no less than 45 degrees. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not horizontal or vertical, but sloping
dictionaryExamples: The picture was hanging at an angle, so I straightened it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I needed to tilt the unit at an angle for it to work. International English Language Testing System; C1; Others

sense.def: the direction from which you look at something
dictionaryExamples: This is the same building photographed from different angles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is possible to see all the paintings from different angles. You can also zoom in and out. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: the way you think about a situation
dictionaryExamples: Try looking at the problem from another angle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be a child is to see the world from a different angle. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in an angry way
dictionaryExamples: "Don't do that!" she shouted angrily.
Demonstrators protested angrily following the jury's verdict.

The Prime Minister reacted angrily to claims that he had lied to
                         the House of Commons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "How dare she do that [to] me?"  I thought, angrily. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: having a strong feeling against someone who has behaved badly, making you want to shout at them or hurt them
dictionaryExamples: He's really angry at/with me for upsetting Sophie.
I don't understand what he's angry about.
They feel angry that their complaints were ignored.
I got really angry with her.
It made me really angry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Ally, I'm so sorry you couldn't come to my birth[d]ay party, but don't worry, I'm not angry with you. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: something that lives and moves but is not a human, bird, fish or insect
dictionaryExamples: wild/domestic animals
She's a real animal lover.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like flowers and baby animals. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: anything that lives and moves, including people, birds, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Are humans the only animals to use language?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the human is [an] animal that want[s] to [do] amusing things. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: An animated film is one in which drawings and models seem to move.
dictionaryExamples: He makes animated films.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a funny animated film about a superhero family. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: showing a lot of interest and excitement
dictionaryExamples: an animated conversation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whether that's true or not is a matter of controversy and animated discussion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: an animated film, or the process of making animated films
dictionaryExamples: a course in computer animation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a comedy animation about penguins. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: the joint  between the foot and the leg, or the thin part of the leg just above the foot
dictionaryExamples: I fell over and sprained/twisted my ankle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have broken my ankle and I need to stay in bed during the day. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the day on which an important event happened in a previous year
dictionaryExamples: We always celebrate our wedding anniversary with dinner at an expensive restaurant.
Tomorrow is the fiftieth anniversary of the revolution.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She and her husband are touring Europe for a second honeymoon, [on the] 10th anniversary of their marriage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to tell people about something officially or with force or confidence
dictionaryExamples: The Prime Minister has just announced that public spending will be increased next year.
The company has announced plans to open six new stores.
After dinner, they announced the winner of the competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] TV has just announced a bus-drivers strike for tomorrow morning. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: something that someone says officially, giving information about something
dictionaryExamples: The President made an unexpected announcement this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard about this club in [a] radio announcement. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone angry
dictionaryExamples: Tim really annoyed me in the meeting this morning.
I'm sorry - is my cough annoying you?
It annoys me that she just expects us to help.
It really annoys me when people expect me to tip as well as pay a service charge in a restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bed makes a loud noise when I lie down on it.  It annoys me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: the feeling of being annoyed
dictionaryExamples: He kept losing his keys, much to the annoyance of his wife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This caused a lot of annoyance, so I suggest next year you make some kind of arrangement [for] booking the places [o]n the computer room in advance. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: angry
dictionaryExamples: I was so annoyed with him for turning up late.
He was annoyed at the way she tried to take over the whole meeting.
My parents were rather annoyed (that) I hadn't told them about the accident.
She was annoyed to discover that her husband had taken her car keys.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was a bit annoyed when I [found out], but it's all right. Key English Test; A2; Gujarati

sense.def: making you feel annoyed
dictionaryExamples: It's really annoying when a train is late and there's no explanation.
He's got a really annoying laugh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you like going shopping with your mom? They are sometimes annoying, aren't they? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: happening once every year, or relating to a period of one year
dictionaryExamples: an annual event/visit/holiday
annual income/salary
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never miss the annual sale at the department store near my place. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: once every year
dictionaryExamples: Your salary will be reviewed annually.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lately I've decided to pick up my old hobby, since I have kept paying for my amateur-radio permit annually. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: not giving a name
dictionaryExamples: an anonymous phone call/letter
The winner has asked to remain anonymous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because the internet does provide the possibility of staying anonymous, it is very hard to find the people wh[o] use it for illegal or criminal actions. International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: one more person or thing, or an additional amount
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to have another piece of cake.
"Would you get me a bar of chocolate from the kitchen?" "Another one?"
For another $30,  you can buy the model with remote control.
Just think, in another three months it'll be summer again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need [it] because I will travel and I don't have another bag. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a different person or thing of the same type
dictionaryExamples: She's finished with that boyfriend and found herself another (one).
Do you want to exchange this toaster for another (one) or do you want your money back?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't need it because I'm going to buy another. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: each other
dictionaryExamples: How can they reach an agreement if they won't talk to one another?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We know one another from Poland. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: used to talk about an occasion in the past without saying exactly which occasion it was
dictionaryExamples: Most of us have made a similar mistake at one time or another.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Haven't we all at one time or another come home from a holiday feeling healthy and strong with a smile on our face thinking, this is what life is about. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: what you say or write back to someone who has asked you a question or spoken to you
dictionaryExamples: I asked him if he was going but I didn't hear his answer.
Please give me your answer by next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, give me [an] answer. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: information given as a reply to a question in a test, exercise, competition, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Did you get the answer to Question 6?
I got eight correct answers and two wrong ones in last week's exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had to fill [in] our question[naire]s and discuss the answers in our class. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: when someone answers the door or telephone
dictionaryExamples: I've just rung him but there was no answer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I called her, but there was no answer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a way of solving a problem
dictionaryExamples: It's a difficult situation and I don't know what the answer is.
So what's the answer to the problem?
There's no easy answer to the problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should wild animals be kept in cages, and denied their freedom so that we can have the pleasure of watching them [in] zoos? Well, there's no simple answer to that question. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to speak or write back to someone who has asked you a question
dictionaryExamples: You haven't answered my question.
I wrote asking whether he'd be coming to the party but he hasn't answered yet.
She answered that she wouldn't be able to come before nine o'clock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher give[s] m[e] questions and I have to answer. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: to open the door to someone or pick up the telephone
dictionaryExamples: Could someone answer the phone?
Someone's at the door - would you answer it, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I phone you, but you don't answer! Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: to write or say something as a reply to a question in a test, exercise, competition, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't answer the last three questions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was to be my first interview, and I had never before answered a test of personality so I felt insecure. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a small, black or red insect that lives in groups on the ground
dictionaryExamples: There were ants crawling all over the ground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [have] know[n] Larry since I was five years old and he couldn't hurt an ant, I am sure about it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a medicine which cures infections by destroying harmful bacteria
dictionaryExamples: He is on antibiotics for an ear infection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, for all the side effects they may have, for all the unpleas[a]ntness of having a needle stuck in your arm or a spoonful of foul-tasting liquid stuck in your mouth, antibiotics and vaccines remain the greatest discovery in the history of the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to expect something, or to prepare for something before it happens
dictionaryExamples: to anticipate a problem
We anticipate that prices will fall next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, it is anticipated that the percentage of the group will rise further in 2010. International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese

sense.def: when you are waiting for something to happen, usually with excitement
dictionaryExamples: The children were breathless with anticipation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yet, what I remember and think is going to stay with me for the rest of my life is that wonderful atmosphere of [a] fairy tale which has come true, that feeling of excitement and anticipation of something marvelous [about] to happen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: expecting something to happen or in preparation for something happening
dictionaryExamples: She's even decorated the spare room in anticipation of your visit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This has sometimes resulted in the comic phenomenon of people traveling to a distant country, in anticipation of encountering strange and original lifestyles, only to come across situations not very different [from] the one they have left in their own countries. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: an object that is old, and often rare or beautiful
dictionaryExamples: an antique shop
My mother collects antiques.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The market opens every Wednesday and you can find a lot of antiques, very interesting people who sell and buy things and delicious food. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: old and often rare or beautiful
dictionaryExamples: antique furniture
antique silver/jewelry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a nice, cosy lobby, with antique furniture and a fireplace. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: antisocial behavior harms society and upsets the people around you
dictionaryExamples: Some critics argued that movies can cause antisocial behavior.

sense.def: An antisocial person does not like being with other people.
dictionaryExamples: I hope they won't think I'm antisocial if I don't go to the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Technology has developed so much that [it] has made us very antisocial. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the feeling of being very worried
dictionaryExamples: Children normally feel a lot of anxiety about their first day at school.
That explains his anxiety over his health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, if we consider this statement in general, we could infer that [the] teenage [years are] quite a good time in a person's life, as there is no stress or anxiety that is usually encountered later on in life. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: worried and nervous
dictionaryExamples: He's very anxious about his exams.
My mother always gets a bit anxious if we're late.
I saw my sister's anxious face at the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I began my courses on Tuesday and I was a little bit anxious but everything was all right. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: wanting to do something or wanting something to happen
dictionaryExamples: I'm anxious to hear her news.
I'm anxious that we get there on time because I don't think there'll be many seats left.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very anxious [for you] to tell me what type of competition you managed to win. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in an anxious way
dictionaryExamples: We waited anxiously  by the phone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am waiting for your reply anxiously. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean some
dictionaryExamples: "Is there any more soup?" "No, I'm afraid there isn't any left."
I haven't seen any of his films.
I asked Andrew for some change but he hasn't got any.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She doesn't [want] any more children. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: one of or each of a particular kind  of person or thing when it is not important which
dictionaryExamples: "Which of these cakes may I eat?" "Any."
Any of you should be able to answer this question.
Any advice that you can give me would be greatly appreciated.
We should hear from him any minute/day/time now.
There were a lot of computers at the store, any (one) of which would have been fine for me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I [was a] child, I like[d] reading any cartoon book, so my parents bought many books for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to emphasize a comparative adjective or adverb
dictionaryExamples: Do you feel any better?
I can't walk any faster.
Those gloves don't look any different than the others.
Houses in this area used to be a real bargain, but they're not cheap any more.
This radio isn't any good - I'll have to buy another.
She couldn't wait any longer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't wait any longer - I had to see Sami. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean "a person or people"
dictionaryExamples: I haven't asked anybody yet.
Does anybody arrive in the office before 7 o'clock?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't need [to] ask anybody. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: any person or any people
dictionaryExamples: Anybody can join the club and membership is free.
The competition is open to anybody under the age of 16.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anybody [could] understand it! Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: despite that
dictionaryExamples: He hates carrots but he ate them anyhow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't a great support, but anyhow I consider my choice to be the best I could have [made]. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: used when you are returning to an earlier subject
dictionaryExamples: Anyhow, as I said, I'll be away next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that we drove for about one hour before we had to take a lunch break. It was still very hot when we continued our trip and we had to stop once more. Anyhow, we [got] to Munich the same day, where we stayed for two days. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionaryExamples: I don't need a car and I can't afford one anyhow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We both thought that it was a good idea to have that stop-over at your place as it was on our route to Norway anyhow. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used when you want to slightly change something that you have just said
dictionaryExamples: Boys aren't horrible - not all of them anyhow!

sense.def: If you do not do something or something does not happen anymore, you have stopped doing it or it does not now happen.
dictionaryExamples: This shirt doesn't fit me anymore - would you like it?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell my radio. I don't use it anymore because I'm going to go to America next week. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean 'a person or people'
dictionaryExamples: I haven't told anyone.
Was there anyone you knew at the meeting?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my cellphone at your house last night[, s]o I can't call anyone. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: any person or any people
dictionaryExamples: Anyone can go - you don't have to be invited.
Anyone could dress well with all that money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If anyone wants to know about more information, please telephone me. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: used  in questions or negatives to mean "something"
dictionaryExamples: Is there anything I can do to help?
I didn't eat anything.
Did you notice anything strange about him?
Was there anything else you wanted to say?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I['m] speaking in class I'm very nervous and I can't say anything. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: any object, event, situation, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Tom will eat anything!
We can do anything you like.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like spag[h]etti or lasagne. But I eat anything. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: used to talk or ask about things of a similar type
dictionaryExamples: Do you want a drink or anything?
Did you do any sightseeing or anything?

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean "similar to"
dictionaryExamples: Does he look anything like his brother?
The pictures on cereal boxes don’t look anything like the actual stuff you eat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even in my dreams I haven't seen anything like it. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: despite that
dictionaryExamples: Her parents were opposed to her quitting school, but she did it anyway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jo, You can call me for th[is] information but I will write it [here] anyway. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used when you are returning to an earlier subject or changing the subject
dictionaryExamples: Anyway, I'll be away next week.
Anyway, in the end I didn't wear your jacket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope everything [will] be O.K... anyway you have my phone number. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech

sense.def: used to give a more important reason for something that you are saying
dictionaryExamples: I don't have time to go and anyway it's too expensive.
Of course I don't mind taking you home - I'm going that way anyway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to buy a new bed, because the old one has broken, [and] anyway it wasn't very comfortable. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: in or to any place
dictionaryExamples: Did you go anywhere interesting this summer?
Go anywhere in the world and you'll find some sort of fast-food restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like that bicycle because I can go anywhere with it without anyone's help. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean "a place"
dictionaryExamples: Is there anywhere in particular you wanted to go to eat tonight?
I can't find my keys anywhere.
Is there anywhere else you'd like to visit?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you know anywhere interesting and how can I get there? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to not make any progress
dictionaryExamples: I tried discussing the problem with her but I didn't get anywhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we think about making an effort and changing our daily routine at once, we will never get anywhere because a drastic change usually does not last. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used in questions and negatives to mean "close to being or doing something"
dictionaryExamples: The house isn't anywhere near ready.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could not have gone anywhere near 5000 miles because all our minibuses were broken down - we even stayed in one place for 8 days. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a set of rooms for living in, especially on one floor of a building
dictionaryExamples: a one-/two-/three-bedroom apartment
I'll give you the keys to my apartment.
They have six luxury apartments for sale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please come to my apartment at 4:00. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: a building containing apartments
dictionaryExamples: We live on the third floor of that apartment building.

sense.def: showing or saying that you are sorry about something
dictionaryExamples: an apologetic smile
She was very apologetic about missing the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am deeply apologetic if my letter troubled anybody or was too boring to read, but I had to say my opinion out loud. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to tell someone that you are sorry about something you have done
dictionaryExamples: I   must apologize to Isobel for my behavior.
Trains may be subject to delay - we apologize for any inconvenience.
She apologized for leaving early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This letter is to inform you that I will not be able to attend tomorrow's class due to medical issues. I apologize for the short notice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something you say or write to say that you are sorry about something you have done
dictionaryExamples: I have an apology to make to you - I'm afraid I opened your letter by mistake.
I owe you an apology, Chris.
"Was he at all sorry for what he'd done?" "Oh he was full of apologies."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Zita, Please accept my apology for this belated letter which you're holding in your hands. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: the  punctuation mark ' which shows when a letter or a number has been left out, or is used before or after "s" to show possession
dictionaryExamples: I'm  Ian.
She was born in '65.
Helen's laugh
Charles' cooking
a baby's hand
babies' hands

sense.def: awful, or shocking and very unpleasant or causing someone to feel upset
dictionaryExamples: The animals were being kept in appalling conditions.
This industry has an appalling environmental record.
Both candidates showed an appalling lack of familiarity with the issues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Susan got the news of his illness all her joy turned into an appalling despair, and she felt she would die too. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: obvious or easy to notice
dictionaryExamples: Her unhappiness was apparent to everyone.
It was becoming increasingly apparent that he could no longer look after himself.
On the subway this morning, the man sitting opposite me suddenly screamed for no apparent reason.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was my Dad, always doing weird things for no apparent reason. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: seeming to exist or be true
dictionaryExamples: I was a little surprised by her apparent lack of interest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your company staff is well known among our club members for its quality but the only apparent flaw we can detect is that they only speak English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say you have read or been told something although you are not certain it is true
dictionaryExamples: Apparently it's going to rain today.
Apparently he's had enough of England and is going back to Australia.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apparently he was planning to visit me and su[r]prise me for my birthday, w[h]ich was the following day. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to say that something seems to be true, although it is not certain
dictionaryExamples: There were two apparently unrelated deaths.
An eighty-year-old woman was badly hurt in what the police describe as an apparently random attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People found it important and still do but apparently, today, we don't appreciate reading as much as our ancestors. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the quality in someone or something that makes them attractive or interesting
dictionaryExamples: Eating out has lost much of its appeal.
Spielberg films have universal/popular appeal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, computer games are so popular because the games have developed their graphics and they have more appeal to youngsters. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a formal or urgent request, especially for money or help in an emergency
dictionaryExamples: They're launching an appeal to raise money for earthquake victims.
The Red Cross issued an appeal for blood donations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would suggest that the local authorities with the support of the community and companies start an appeal, to raise money to keep the St. Mary's running. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to attract or interest someone
dictionaryExamples: Cycling has never really appealed to me.
It's a program designed to appeal mainly to 16 to 25 year-olds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, books appeal to our imagination. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a serious or formal request, especially for money or help
dictionaryExamples: They're appealing for clothes and blankets to send to the devastated region.
The police are appealing to the public for any information about the missing girl.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact so much [did] he like English that he was one of the first to appeal for a place in the "Erasmus," a scheme allowing students to study in foreign countries of their choice. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to start to be seen
dictionaryExamples: He suddenly appeared in the doorway.
Then a bright light appeared in the sky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly the singer of the band appeared. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to perform in a movie, play, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She appears briefly in the new James Bond movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I like the most is that I'm going to appear on T.V. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to seem
dictionaryExamples: He appeared calm and relaxed.
There appears to be some mistake.
The governor appeared confident of another election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, [the] reality is, that life appears very short to me.  My first impression in my new class was that the teacher was bad and [too] serious, but it appears that he is very nice. (1094174; Preliminary English Test; Switzerland; B1 THRESHOLD; 2002; French; Pass)Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: used to say that something seems to be true
dictionaryExamples: It appears that he had asked someone to drive him home from the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It appears that people are more aware about clothes and also work. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to start to exist or become available
dictionaryExamples: Laptop computers first appeared in the 1980s.
The story appeared in all the major newspapers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In almost every city fast-food restaurants [have] appear[ed], which have a big group of fans. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that something seems to be true
dictionaryExamples: It would appear that nobody on board the aircraft actually had a licence to fly it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would appear that students are not satisfied with the hours and days offered by the Club. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the way a person or thing looks to other people
dictionaryExamples: The buildings are very similar in appearance.
You can alter/change the whole appearance of a room just by lighting it in a certain way.
She gives the appearance of being very efficient.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I usually buy fashionable clothes, because I think [your] appearance is really important. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when someone appears in public, on television, in a film, etc.
dictionaryExamples: It was his first appearance on television/television appearance as president.
She made two appearances during her visit.
She will be making a public appearance, signing copies of her latest novel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You probably know him, because he [made] an appearance [i]n the film "Bad Boys." First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when something starts to exist or becomes available
dictionaryExamples: The appearance of new products on the market has increased competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The appearance of the car has facilitated our lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the feeling that you want to eat
dictionaryExamples: a good/healthy appetite
All that walking gave me quite an appetite.
If I have a snack now it will spoil my appetite and I won't want dinner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The tasteless food spoiled our appetite. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when you want something very much
dictionaryExamples: He has a real appetite for adventure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It does not occur to him that Jack has degenerated into blood-lust and is driven by hatred and an appetite for power. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to clap your hands to show that you have enjoyed a performance, talk, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The audience applauded loudly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, owing to a sudden shower, there was a short break during the dance display and the horse show, but eventually, we finished the display and the show successfully and people applauded. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to approve of or admire something
dictionaryExamples: Most people will surely applaud the decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I admire and applaud Stevens' integrity and dignity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: when people make a noise by clapping their hands to show they have enjoyed or approve of something
dictionaryExamples: There was loud applause at the end of her speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Still the audience was very pleased, because they gave massive applause at the end. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: when people clap
dictionaryExamples: The crowd gave him a huge round of applause.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was unbelievable, there was a round of applause and some people couldn't help crying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a hard, round fruit that has a green or red skin and is white inside
dictionaryExamples: to peel an apple
apple pie/sauce
an apple tree
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The place is in North Iraq. I like this place, becaus[e] it [has] very nice w[ea]ther, and [there is] nice fruit: dates, grapes, peach[es], [and] apple[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: a piece of electrical equipment with a particular purpose in the home
dictionaryExamples: home/household/kitchen appliances
You should look for the most energy-efficient appliances.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fair was well organized and structured into specific sections from clothing and sportswear to household appliances and electronic [goods]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: an official request for something, usually in writing
dictionaryExamples: a job/college application
I've sent off applications for four different jobs.
Have you filled in the application form for your passport yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After having filled [in] the application form, the master pilot took us on a short trip around the hangars showing the planes used for training. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a piece of computer software designed for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: Typical examples of software applications are spreadsheets, media players and database applications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am [an] exp[e]rienced user of [the] Internet and know all application programs for Windows '95 (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, PinPoint etc.). First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a way in which something can be used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: This technology has many practical applications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have been working [o]n the growing of cells in zero-gravity environments, having in mind its possible application in outer space colonies, such as the International Space Station. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to request something, usually officially, especially by writing or sending in a form
dictionaryExamples: By the time I saw the job advertised it was already too late to apply.
I've applied for a job there.
Please apply in writing to the address below.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I applied for this course and went to my first lesson last week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to relate to a particular person or situation
dictionaryExamples: The same rules apply to everybody.
Those were old regulations - they don't apply any more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The same doesn't apply to a teenager who lives in illness and poverty and whose family and friends constantly mistreat him. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to use something in a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: The same method can be applied to other situations.
As a translator, he was able to apply his knowledge of foreign languages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, he can explain how theory is being applied in the field. International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi

sense.def: to work hard
dictionaryExamples: If he doesn't apply himself, he'll never pass his exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many previously unknown professions emerged, [and] people started to apply themselves to their jobs much more than before; the p[u]rsuit [of] money was initiated. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to officially choose someone for a job
dictionaryExamples: She was appointed by the governor.
He was appointed director last year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was appointed by the gover[n]ment as head of a newly established task force. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: a time you have arranged to meet someone or go somewhere
dictionaryExamples: a dentist/doctor's appointment
I'd like to make an appointment to see Doctor Evans, please.
I canceled  the appointment.
I've got a two o'clock appointment.
That's the second appointment he's missed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother is taking me to a dentist appointment. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: when you officially choose someone for an important job, or the job itself
dictionaryExamples: the appointment of three new teachers
a temporary appointment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His outstanding successful work on fowl vaccine was rewarded by his appointment to lecturer in veterinary microbiology and hygiene. Soon all vet students liked him very much. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to understand how good something is or how difficult it was
dictionaryExamples: There's no point buying him expensive clothes - he doesn't appreciate them.
I don't think you appreciate how much time I spent preparing this meal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure you will appreciate the food, even if the services is not so good. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used when you are politely requesting something
dictionaryExamples: I would appreciate it if you could let me know  in advance whether or not you will be coming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would really appreciate a positive answer from your side. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used when you are thanking someone or showing that you are grateful
dictionaryExamples: Thanks for all the help you gave us last weekend. We really appreciate it.
I appreciate your making the effort to come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thanks for your congratulations. I really appreciate it. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to understand something about a situation, especially that it is complicated or difficult
dictionaryExamples: I appreciate that it is a difficult decision for you to make.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Given the size of the house and the rather delicate nature of some of the furniture pieces, I appreciate that it may have been somewhat of a challenge. International English Language Testing System; C2; Russian

sense.def: when you understand how good or how difficult something is
dictionaryExamples: To show our appreciation for all your help, we bought you a little gift.
The crowd cheered in appreciation.
My appreciation of art has increased as I've gotten older.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To show our appreciation, we would also like to invite you to dinner afterwards at the Red Baron. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to come close in distance or time
dictionaryExamples: The train was approaching the station.
Christmas is fast approaching.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided to approach the house since the situation looked very strange for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to deal with something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not sure how to approach the problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is the right way to approach the issue. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a way of doing something
dictionaryExamples: In Sweden they have a different approach to the problem.
I thought we'd adopt/take a new approach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This will show the contrast in teaching methods, different approaches to students and [the] techniques used by different teachers. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when something or someone gets nearer in distance or time
dictionaryExamples: The siren signaled the approach of an ambulance.
Please fasten your seat belts, the plane is now making its final approach (in)to  Heathrow Airport.

sense.def: suitable or right for a particular situation or occasion
dictionaryExamples: Is this film appropriate for small children?
I didn't think his comments were very appropriate at the time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will explain why I am an appropriate person for this job. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: in a way that is appropriate
dictionaryExamples: She didn't think we were appropriately dressed for a wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoyed reading it and I think it appropriately describes the atmosphere of that lovely town. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when you have a positive opinion of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He showed his approval by smiling broadly.
Sam always tried hard to win his father's approval.
Does the wine meet with your approval?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope this meets [with] your approval and I am looking forward to hearing from you as soon as possible. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: official permission
dictionaryExamples: We need approval for the project to move ahead.
The teacher gave the student a nod of approval.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides the questionable approval given by governmental authorities, the situation might be useful to us. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to allow or officially agree to something
dictionaryExamples: The town has approved plans for a new shopping center.
The court approved the sale of the property.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Congratulation[s], your scholarship to [the] UK is approved." Preliminary English Test; B1; Assamese

sense.def: to think that something is good or right
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't approve of my friends.
He doesn't approve of smoking.
The head of the department seems to approve of what I am doing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Woods didn't approve of the government's attitude to them. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: not completely accurate but close
dictionaryExamples: Their approximate arrival time is 10:30.
These figures/numbers are approximate.
Do you know the approximate size of the rooms??
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The  approximate figure is about 5000 people. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: close to a particular number or time although not exactly that number or time
dictionaryExamples: The job will take approximately two weeks, and cost around $2000.
The school has approximately 700 students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the airport of Larnaka you need approximately forty-five minutes by taxi, to Agia Napa. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: the fourth month of the year, after March and before May
dictionaryExamples: the 20th of April/April 20(th)
The meeting was held on the fourth of April/April fourth.
I took a course in London last April.
I'm taking a course in London next April.
We came back in April.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class is on the second of April and it will be three hours long. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: not based on a system or principles and often seeming unfair
dictionaryExamples: an arbitrary decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To start with, this arbitrary act is, as far as I am concerned, one of the worst aggressions to nature, as an area of about two miles of gre[e]n[e]ry will have to be completely destroyed to give [a] place to an absurd parking garage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a curved structure that usually supports something, for example a bridge or wall
dictionaryExamples: Passing through the arch, you enter an open courtyard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She could have taken a short cut, but she chose this long and rather uncomfortable way deliberately, as it was leading past the old arch where a strange man used to play a violin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be a curved shape or make something become a curved shape
dictionaryExamples: The bridge arched over the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly a flash arched across the sky, followed by an echoing rumble. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who studies ancient cultures by looking for and examining their buildings, tools, and other objects
dictionaryExamples: Archaeologists believe the remains date back to the 5th century.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It includes articles from prominent journalists, scientists, archaeologists and other experts on Greek civilisation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the study of ancient cultures by looking for and examining their buildings, tools, and other objects
dictionaryExamples: He studied archaeology in college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I have to admit that there could be more presentations to cover areas like archaeology, language, etc. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: someone whose job is to  design buildings
dictionaryExamples: Who is the architect who designed this building?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He kn[e]w that I wanted to be an architect. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the design and style of buildings
dictionaryExamples: Roman architecture
modern architecture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are beautiful places like Merarejonban, which is outstanding in its architecture.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the skill of designing buildings
dictionaryExamples: He studied architecture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to study architecture in the U.K. but English is a problem, so I need spend a lot of time learn[ing] it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a region of a country or city
dictionaryExamples: All areas of the country will have some rain tonight.
Housing in the Boston area is very expensive.
This is a very poor area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a tourist area. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a part of a building or piece of land used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a play/picnic area
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm staying in a very big hotel; it ha[s] a swimming pool, a golf area, gardens, and also a children['s] area. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: a part of a subject or activity
dictionaryExamples: Marketing is Paul's area.
Software is not really my area of expertise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a 30-year-old Swedish male with a diploma in gardening. I have 6 years experience of the area since I have been employed by a Swedish fruit supplier. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to speak angrily to someone, telling them that you disagree with them
dictionaryExamples: My parents are always arguing.
Kids, will you stop arguing with each other?
They were arguing over/about which movie to go see.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter told her his parents had argued and he came with his mother to London. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to give reasons to support or oppose an idea, action, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Several people argued in favor of creating bike lanes on the avenue.
She argued against tax cuts.
The mayor argued that cuts in all departments are needed to balance the budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is often argued that family life is not important. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an angry discussion with someone in which you both disagree
dictionaryExamples: The children had an argument about/over what game to play.
He got into an argument with a man in the restaurant last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wrote a song last week. It's about my boyfriend and an argument he had with his parents about our relationship. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a reason or reasons why you support or oppose an idea, action, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There are many arguments for and against nuclear energy.
I don't think that's a very strong/powerful argument.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One final argument for the use of the bicycle is that bicycles don't create pollution. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: very dry and without enough rain for plants
dictionaryExamples: an arid region/climate
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first thing I have noticed, during my arrival, was the impressive number of trees seen even from the plane windows. That was a big surprise for someone growing up in such an arid country as Greece. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If a problem arises, it starts to happen.
dictionaryExamples: The whole problem arose from a lack of communication.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although the place was very good, a number of problems arose during our visit. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the long part at each side of the human body, ending in a hand
dictionaryExamples: My arms ache from carrying this bag.
She put/threw her arms around me, and hugged me to her.
He took/held her in his arms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've a Tennis racket that I bought a year ago. I want to sell it because I've broken my arm. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the part of a chair where your arm rests
dictionaryExamples: The chair didn't have any arms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It appears to me that the leather covering the left arm of the sofa has been pierced with some sharp object. International English Language Testing System; C2; Marathi

sense.def: with your arm gently supporting or being supported by someone else's arm
dictionaryExamples: They walked through the park, arm in arm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We often walked around the playground arm in arm. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to not allow someone to become too friendly with you
dictionaryExamples: I always had the feeling she was keeping me at arm's length.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first she keeps them at arm's length, but Mr. Emerson is direct and advises Lucy to behave in a more natural way instead of doing what some old ladies say. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a comfortable chair with sides that support your arms
dictionaryExamples: She sat in an armchair by the fire, reading a newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell my armchair and my television. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: using or carrying weapons
dictionaryExamples: an armed robbery
armed conflict
armed guards/police
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could clearly understand that the two armed men would catch us within [a] few minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: carrying or knowing something that will be useful
dictionaryExamples: I like to go to a meeting armed with the relevant facts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is not a young executive woman armed with a portable computer and three telephones. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to surround or be on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionaryExamples: We sat around the table.
He put his arm around her.
The moon goes around the Earth.
I walked around the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go around the lake by train. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: to or in different parts of a place
dictionaryExamples: I spent a year traveling around Australia.
I used to live around here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that, we will walk around the shopping mall. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: about or approximately
dictionaryExamples: around two months ago
around four o'clock
She earns around forty thousand a year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll go by car and I'll be there around 3:30 pm. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: all day and all night
dictionaryExamples: Rescue teams are working around the clock to search for survivors of the earthquake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is undeniable that people are working around the clock in order to earn a living. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to or in different parts of a place
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to fly to Peru and travel around for six weeks.
She went into town and spent two hours just walking around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Come and visit, I'll show you around. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: in a circle or with circular movement
dictionaryExamples: She passed a plate of biscuits around.
This switch makes the wheels go around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hello, everybody. Please gather around. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to the opposite direction
dictionaryExamples: Jonny turned around and looked at her.
The pianist spun around on the stool and faced his audience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I turned around. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: If someone  is around, they are present in a place.
dictionaryExamples: Will you be around next week?
Roger isn't around at the moment - can I help instead?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was dark and not a soul was around. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: present or available
dictionaryExamples: Cell phones have been around for years now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Major sport[s] competitions have been around for the better part of 2500 years, ever since the original Olympic Games were held in ancient Greece. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone have a particular feeling or reaction
dictionaryExamples: It's a subject which has aroused a lot of interest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was something about her that had aroused my interest. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to make the necessary plans and preparations for something to happen
dictionaryExamples: We've arranged a meeting for Wednesday.
They arranged to have dinner the following month.
I've already arranged with him where to meet.
She's arranged for her son to have swimming lessons.
I'd arranged that they should arrive at the same time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Friends, It's a fantastic idea to come to my country [for] the holidays; we could arrange to meet somewhere. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to put objects in a particular order or position
