dictionaryExamples: She arranged her birthday cards along the shelf.
Who arranged these flowers so beautifully?
His books are neatly arranged in alphabetical order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before the pop concert [started], I arranged the seats and carried some musical instruments. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: plans for how something will happen
dictionaryExamples: They'd made all the arrangements for the party.
Arrangements were made to move the prisoners to another jail.
What are your current childcare arrangements?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll make all [the] arrangements. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: an agreement between two people or groups
dictionaryExamples: We had an arrangement that he would clean the house and I would cook.
I'm sure we can come to an arrangement.
You can only withdraw money from this account by (prior) arrangement  with the bank.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't know if you would be in the house or not so you need to contact him for a new arrangement [on] this telephone number 333-30.30.  First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a group of objects in a particular order or position
dictionaryExamples: a flower arrangement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mrs. Anderson, I have learned from a friend that your club gives advanced courses in flower arrangement. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If the police arrest someone, they take them away to ask them about a crime which they might have committed.
dictionaryExamples: She was arrested for drinking and driving.
He was arrested when customs officers found drugs in his bag.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To my horror, they arrested me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: when the police take someone away to ask them about a crime which they might have committed
dictionaryExamples: Police made twenty arrests at yesterday's demonstration.
She was stopped outside the store and placed under arrest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came around, Mr. Smith was under arrest and fortunately, thing[s] finished well for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone or something arrives somewhere
dictionaryExamples: Hundreds gathered to await the boxer's arrival at the airport.
On arrival at the police station, they were taken to a room for questioning.
We regret the late arrival of flight 237.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you confirm your arrival time next week? Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: a new thing or person that has arrived
dictionaryExamples: Two teachers were there to greet the new arrivals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, a barbecue would be a good thing to do on the 1st of September, to welcome the new arrivals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: when something new is discovered or created or becomes available
dictionaryExamples: The arrival of the railroad changed the western US.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the arrival of capitalism, the mass-production of garments inherent to this system has raised the issue of whether what people wear reflects their personality. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to reach a place, especially at the end of a journey
dictionaryExamples: What time does your train arrive?
It was dark by the time we arrived at the station.
We arrived in Prague later that day.
I ordered some DVDs over a month ago, but they still haven't arrived.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm arriving at four o'clock. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: to make a decision about something after a lot of thought
dictionaryExamples: We didn't arrive at any firm conclusions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [This is] something very important which should be discussed... We may arrive at a conclusion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: believing that you are better or more important than other people
dictionaryExamples: I found him arrogant and rude.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chubby, arrogant and filthy were the words that described him best. Every time they met, a bitter feeling of hatre[d] bloomed in her throat. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a symbol used on a sign, on a computer, etc. to show direction
dictionaryExamples: I followed the arrows to the parking lot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I followed its arrow and believe it or not I found m[o]m! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a weapon that is like a long, thin stick with a sharp point at one end and often feathers at the other, shot from a bow
dictionaryExamples: Robin Hood asked to be buried where his arrow landed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The museum has many old axes, crossbows, bows and arrows. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the making or study of paintings, drawings, etc. or the objects created
dictionaryExamples: modern art
an art exhibition/gallery
Art and English were my best subjects at school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The new art class after school is on Wednesday. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: creative areas including painting, drama, dance, music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: fine/decorative arts
the performing arts
Cory's career in arts management has led her from the philharmonic to the Metropolitan Opera.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can enjoy both traditional and contemporary performing arts in Osaka. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: subjects, such as history, languages and philosophy, that are not scientific subjects
dictionaryExamples: the School/College of Arts and Sciences
a Bachelor/Master of Arts degree
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For Arts and Science graduates, gaining a degree meant better prospects. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: a piece of writing on a particular subject in a newspaper or magazine
dictionaryExamples: There was an interesting article on climate change in the paper yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read an article about this zoo in the newspaper. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: in grammar, used to mean the words "a," "an" and "the"
dictionaryExamples: There's a definite article missing before the noun.

sense.def: not natural, but made by people
dictionaryExamples: an artificial flower/lake
artificial flavors
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Zoos are artificial settings for animals. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not sincere
dictionaryExamples: an artificial smile
Their cheerfulness seemed strained and artificial.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Miss Bartlett probably comes from the poorer part of the family and that is why she always tries to show her unselfishness to Lucy but this is done in a very artificial and annoying way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the use of computer programs that can copy some qualities of the human mind, such as the ability to understand language and 	to learn from experience, or the study of how this can be done
dictionaryExamples: A robot with true artificial intelligence hasn't been invented.
This is a clearly written, but extremely superficial, introduction to the field of artificial intelligence (AI).
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: True artificial intelligence, one of the most terrifying dreams of man, is yet to be discovered, but we must handle it with great care if we don't want to suffer the consequences of a world in which machines start to think for us, this making our exist[e]nce completely pointless. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: in an artificial way
dictionaryExamples: Most mushrooms sold in supermarkets have been grown artificially in manure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Zoos are part of nature, despite the fact that they are  created artificially. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: someone who paints, draws or makes sculptures
dictionaryExamples: Monet is one of my favorite artists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring a pencil and paintings to copy [by] famous artists like Goya. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: showing skill and imagination in creating things, especially in painting, drawing, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Both children are very artistic.
artistic talent
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the museum is a place were they can say how they feel, or express it in an abstract or artistic way, they will start to like it. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: relating to any form of art, including painting, literature, theater, music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the artistic director of the theater
a work of artistic merit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That would be perfect to improve the artistic and cultural life of Turin. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used to talk about the job someone has
dictionaryExamples: She works as a waitress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He work[s] in a school as a teacher. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: also
dictionaryExamples: Are you going to invite Steve as well?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dylma goes to school every day and work[s] as well. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: in addition to
dictionaryExamples: They have lived in the United States as well as Britain.
We have a responsibility to our community as well as to our families.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like pop as well as country music. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: like or in the same way
dictionaryExamples: We used the box as a table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is very useful because you can use it as a camera. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to compare two things, people, amounts, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She'll soon be as tall as her mother.
I can't run as fast as you.
The food here isn't as good as it used to be.
She earns three times as much as I do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The air isn't as good as in the countryside because of the pollution. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: as much/quickly/soon, etc. as something can happen or be done
dictionaryExamples: Please sit down as quickly as possible.
I'll go as soon as possible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need it as soon as possible. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: in the way that happens most of the time
dictionaryExamples: As usual, James was the last to arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As usual, I'll travel by plane. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: being or appearing to be a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: He was dressed as a pirate.
As a young man, he was very lonely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was there, standing in front of me, still dressed as a bride, with tears in her eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at the same time or a very short time after
dictionaryExamples: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as the rain stopped, I called my friend and we all continued walking in the park, and we all enjoyed ourselves. Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian

sense.def: used to say that something must happen before something else can happen
dictionaryExamples: I can come as long as I can leave by 4:00.
Sure, you can bring your friends - just as long as I know how many are coming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The colors I wear are not important, as long as I don't wear any pink clothes. I really dislike that color. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce a slightly different subject, but one that is connected in some way
dictionaryExamples: I was pleased about the news. As for Emily, well, who cares what she thinks?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, as for the camping, I admit that I'm not a great f[a]n of it. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: because of something
dictionaryExamples: Unemployment has risen as a result of the credit crunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n more than one oc[c]asion I missed the new releases or arrived late, as a result of trusting the [theater's] website. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when considered as a group and not in parts
dictionaryExamples: The population as a whole is getting healthier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, I can say that the greatest ever invention is the invention of computers, that has affected both indivi[d]uals and society as a whole. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
dictionaryExamples: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big tournament.
"So you're from Cambridge?" "As a matter of fact, I live across the river, in Boston."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used to introduce a list or description
dictionaryExamples: The main reasons are as follows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The errors made in the newspaper are as follows. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionaryExamples: It looks as if it might rain.
It was as though we had known each other for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything was so familiar, as though he [had] never left the place. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

blocks.phrase: as far as sb is concerned

sense.def: used to show what someone thinks about something
dictionaryExamples: As far as I'm concerned, feng shui is just nonsense.
As far as our customers are concerned, price is the main consideration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as Laura was concerned, he was the most disgusting man in the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

blocks.phrase: as far as sth is concerned

sense.def: used to tell someone what you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: As far as money is concerned, we're doing very well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I think the Majestic Hotel would be the right location, but I have doubts as far as the costs are concerned. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionaryExamples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as I know this hotel is very comfortable. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that you say in order to introduce a surprising fact
dictionaryExamples: As it happens, her birthday is the day after mine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As it happens, I am currently looking for a computer course for myself and I would like to join one of your courses. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hebrew

sense.def: used before a number or amount to show that the number or amount is large
dictionaryExamples: As many as 6,000 people may have been infected with the disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The quantities of goods by pipeline in 2002 was approximately 10 times as many as that in 1974, 21 and 2 million tonnes respectively. International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese

sense.def: until and including this time
dictionaryExamples: I haven't heard as yet if their flight has arrived.
No ambulances had as yet managed to get across the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to do something about it, but as I can't imagine building anything near my beautiful house (because I'm afraid it would destroy its wonderful harmony), I have no idea as yet how to solve this problem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: used to talk about one thing that is the result of another
dictionaryExamples: A lot of birds died as a consequence of the oil spill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The influence from Italy is very strong and, as a consequence, pasta with different s[a]uces is common in Slovenia, especially among students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionaryExamples: A "suggested price" is, as the name implies, the sale price suggested by the manufacturer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sour Sweet, as the name implies, is originally a Chinese restaurant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: rather than or instead of
dictionaryExamples: I’d prefer to go in May, as opposed to September.
I'm talking about English football, as opposed to American football.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: What is more important, the majority of shoppers have changed their attitude to shop[ping] radically.  
 They now take it as something engrossing and satisfying as opposed to what it used to be - tiring, exhausting and infuriating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: as something is now, without changes in it
dictionaryExamples: The law as it stands is very unclear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: because
dictionaryExamples: As it was getting late, I decided to check into a hotel.
You can go first as you're the oldest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need it as I have to return it to the library. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: while or during the time that
dictionaryExamples: I saw him as I was coming into the building.
He gets more attractive as he gets older.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After spending two hours searching for her I started to feel desperate, but just as I was ready to give up, the sky got normal again and I found myself [at] my own wedding and she was my wife! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in the same way
dictionaryExamples: He got divorced, (just) as his parents had done years before.
This year, as in previous years, tickets sold very quickly.
As with his earlier movies, the special effects in his latest movie are brilliant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As we expected, we are going to see a movie tonight. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: feeling guilty or embarrassed about something you have done
dictionaryExamples: You've got nothing to be ashamed of.
She ought to be ashamed of herself - talking to her mother like that!
He was ashamed to admit to his mistake.
I was ashamed that I'd made so little effort.
I felt so ashamed of myself for making such a fuss.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He felt very ashamed and didn't know what to do. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be angry and disappointed with a family member or friend because they have behaved badly
dictionaryExamples: My brother was so rude to Jane - I was ashamed of him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was very ashamed of them. [They] came from [my] own country. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: on or to one side
dictionaryExamples: Stand aside, please, and let these people pass.
He pulled the curtain aside.
I gave her a plate of food but she pushed it aside.
She took me aside to tell me the news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw an old man slowly pull it aside and peep out, looking [at] the street with his eyes wide open. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If you put or set something aside, you do not use it now, but keep it to use later.
dictionaryExamples: We've put some money aside for our vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had put some money aside for a month, thinking about the discount. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: except for
dictionaryExamples: This document needs finishing, but aside from that I think everything is done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, it is unfair to say the other performers were second-rate aside from the Torrents, since they all sang and played very well. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to say a question to someone which you want them to answer
dictionaryExamples: She asked me a question.
Can I ask you something?
She asked me about my parents.
I asked why the plane was so late.
"Why is Sara crying?" he asked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You asked me about a day at college. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: to invite someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: I've asked David to the party.
I've asked David to come to the party.
"Are you going to Muriel's party?" "No, I haven't been asked."
Ian's asked us over for dinner next Friday.
Ian's asked us to dinner next Friday.
In fact they've asked us to stay for the whole weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for asking me to your wedding. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Thai

sense.def: to say something to someone because you want them to do something
dictionaryExamples: They've asked me to look after their dog while they're away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to apologize for not going to your class tomorrow, it's not that I don't want to go but my mother asked me to take care of my sister because she is s[ic]k and my parents have to work. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to say something to someone because you want them to give you something
dictionaryExamples: He's asked for a bike for his birthday.
He's asked us for a new bike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can ask my parents for a stereo for Christmas, but I'm not sure if they will agree or not. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to say something to someone because you want to know if you can do something
dictionaryExamples: Bruce asked if he could stay with us for a few days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to travel with my girlfriend Anna, so I am writing you this email to ask if you can lend me your bicycle for a week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: said when someone asks you about an experience that was very bad
dictionaryExamples: "How was the meeting?" "Don't ask!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't ask me how the concert was! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to tell someone that you do not know the answer to a question and that you are surprised they have asked you
dictionaryExamples: "So why would she leave such a good job?" "Don't ask me!"

sense.def: said when giving your opinion on something
dictionaryExamples: If you ask me, he doesn't really care about his friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you ask me, the things that matter in a job are the people [you] work with and feeling happy about the work you are doing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to think about something carefully
dictionaryExamples: You've got to ask yourself whether it's what you really want.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to ask yourself what life is worth in these situations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: sleeping or not awake
dictionaryExamples: The children are asleep.
I fell asleep as soon as my head hit the pillow.
I'm surprised to see you awake - ten minutes ago you were fast/sound asleep.
I've only just got up and I'm still half asleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I prefer reading alone, when I'm in my bed before I fall asleep. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If part of your body is asleep, you cannot feel it.
dictionaryExamples: My arm fell asleep.

sense.def: completely asleep
dictionaryExamples: I looked into his room but he was still  fast asleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then she took a relaxing bath and 20 minutes later she was fast asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: one part of a situation, problem, subject, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Which aspects of the job do you most enjoy?
That's the most worrying aspect of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every aspect of our daily life is influenced by technology. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: something that you hope to achieve
dictionaryExamples: I've never had any political aspirations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A career should reflect a person's beliefs and aspirations, not their bank account. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: a common drug used to reduce pain and fever
dictionaryExamples: I took a couple of aspirin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took an aspirin quickly. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an attack
dictionaryExamples: an assault on a police officer
sexual assault
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rapes, assaults, murders, burglaries, [and] robberies have been so frequent that a lot of technological progress has been made in order to prevent these from happening. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to attack someone violently
dictionaryExamples: He was assaulted by a minor who cannot be named.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is said that the boat was coming back to Boston's Port after having assaulted a royal ship and taken all its treasures when it came across this hurr[i]cane, Hurr[i]cane Hugo. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to build something by joining parts together
dictionaryExamples: Their furniture is easy to assemble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The people of the nearby town suffer from unemployment and this makes the Town Hall dignitaries take a package of measures, for example, build a plant [for] assembling cars where thousands of people will be employed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to join other people somewhere to make a group, or to bring people together into a group
dictionaryExamples: They assembled in the meeting room after lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Soon a rescue team was assembled by experienced skiers and climbers, and started com[b]ing the mountain looking for the missing snowboarder. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a group of people, such as a government, who meet to make decisions, laws, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The state assembly will vote on a tax bill next week.
the United Nations General Assembly
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope that it won't be necessary to talk to our local Assembly represent[ative], because that would only make this process longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when you build something by attaching parts together
dictionaryExamples: The frame needs to be strong enough to support the engine assembly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The spring beneath one of the 3 seats integrated with the sofa assembly also seems to be broken. International English Language Testing System; C2; Marathi

sense.def: to say that something is certainly true
dictionaryExamples: He asserts that she stole money from him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It could be asserted that less financially able children are better equipped to cope with potential life problems than the more fortunate children. International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai

sense.def: to behave or speak in a strong, confident way
dictionaryExamples: She has to learn to assert herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Such an attitude may also be the result of little pangs of homesickness or of our need to assert ourselves, to feel superior in a foreign country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to do something to show other people that you have power
dictionaryExamples: She soon asserted her authority as leader.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He can assert his authority over all the boys who are there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: behaving or speaking in a strong, confident way
dictionaryExamples: You need to be much more assertive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to learn how to be more assertive, find emotional independence, fulfil my dreams, be more tolerant, less sarcastic and, most importantly, be given the precious gift of patience. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a judgement about the quality, size or value, etc. of something
dictionaryExamples: Examinations are a way of assessing a student's ability.
They assessed the cost of the flood damage at £1500.
We need to assess whether the project is worth doing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this report is to compare and assess the architecture, food and service of two restaurants in my area. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when you make a judgement about the quality, size or value, etc. of something
dictionaryExamples: That's a fair assessment of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, I was a little bit upset about your assessment of [the] other performers because they showed us their great musical talents. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a person, skill or quality that is useful or helps you to succeed
dictionaryExamples: He'll be a great asset to the team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure that you will be more than satisfied with him and that he is going to be an asset to your hotel. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something which a person or company owns that has a value
dictionaryExamples: The company has $70 billion in assets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Somehow, all his assets were frozen by the bank and the family became poor overnight. International English Language Testing System; C1; Akan

sense.def: to give someone a particular job or responsibility
dictionaryExamples: UN forces were assigned the task of rebuilding the hospital.
The case has been assigned to our most senior officer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of the work they were assigned was quite boring for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to give someone a particular job or place to work
dictionaryExamples: Which police officer has been assigned to this case?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was assigned to Sanming Police Station. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a piece of work, especially school work, or a job that you are given to do
dictionaryExamples: a vocabulary/reading/math assignment
The assignment is due on Friday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll ask Susan about today's assignments. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to help
dictionaryExamples: The army arrived to assist in the search.
You will be expected to assist the editor with the selection of illustrations for the book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I used to assist my brother, who is a photographer. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: help
dictionaryExamples: Can I be of any assistance?
Teachers can't give pupils any assistance during exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your assistance. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an organization of people with the same interests or with  a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: the American Medical Association
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a member of the local Kung-Fu Association. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: working together with
dictionaryExamples: The event was organized in association with the Student Council.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This service, which will be [provided] in association with Foster Loft, will be available at the end of 2005. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: a connection or relationship between two things or people
dictionaryExamples: There is no association between the two groups.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second example is people who wear clothes such as black le[a]ther suits and black or purple lip-stick, showing their association with a particular genre of music. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to think that something is true, without question or proof
dictionaryExamples: I assumed (that) you knew each other because you went to the same school.
I invited her just assuming she would want to come.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The police assumed he was lying so they put him [in] jail. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to take a position of control/power/responsibility, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He has assumed the role of spokesman for the group.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She got involved in the marketing business there and assumed responsibility very soon - she became the marketing director for continental Europe. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: something that you think is true without having any proof
dictionaryExamples: People tend to make assumptions about you when you have a disability.
These calculations are based on the assumption that prices will continue to rise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But if this assumption is right, and if you consider how much fashion has changed over the last 60 years, does this mean that we are so very different from our grandparents? Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a promise
dictionaryExamples: He gave us his assurance that it would not happen again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Again, may I give my assurances that the above two requests [for] equipment acquisition would be money well spent for our company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: confidence
dictionaryExamples: He spoke with calm assurance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I urge you to stay calm and wait for the rescue team," said Mark with assurance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to tell someone confidently that something is true, especially so that they do not worry
dictionaryExamples: She assured him (that) the car would be ready the next day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can assure you that the food will be delicious. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make something certain to happen
dictionaryExamples: This loan should assure the company's future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The PT is guaranteed to assure higher test results or your money back! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: very surprised
dictionaryExamples: I was astonished to see Miriam there.
They looked astonished when I announced I was pregnant.
The doctors were astonished at the speed of her recovery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was astonished when she saw what [wa]s in front of her. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: very surprising
dictionaryExamples: Her first novel enjoyed an astonishing level of success.
It's astonishing to think that only a few years ago Communism dominated eastern Europe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Lakeside Inn, is not an expensive one, at all, it has got a good restaurant, nice service and an astonishing view of Lake Frene. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: very great surprise
dictionaryExamples: To my astonishment, she started laughing.
She gasped in astonishment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To our astonishment, we were in front of a small house which seemed to have been built centuries ago. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the scientific study of stars and planets
dictionaryExamples: This is the biggest step forward in astronomy since Galileo's first telescope over four hundred years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her father was famous for his vast knowledge of astronomy and books he wrote on this subject. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used to show the place or position of something
dictionaryExamples: She's at home/work.
We met at the station.
We'll meet you at the entrance.
She's sitting at the table in the corner.
She was standing at the top of the stairs.
There's someone at the door.
We spent the afternoon at a tennis match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I met [her] at sewing classes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: used to show the time something happens
dictionaryExamples: There's a meeting at 2:30 this afternoon.
Are you free at lunchtime?
In theory, women can still have children at the age of 50.
I'm busy at the moment - can you call back later?
At no point did the company do anything illegal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I go to work at 7:30. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: toward or in the direction of
dictionaryExamples: She smiled at me.
They waved at us as we drove by.
"Look at me! Look at me!" called the little girl.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like walk[ing] around these lakes and look[ing] at ducks and swans. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the @ symbol, used in e-mail addresses to separate the name of a person, department, etc. from the name of the company
dictionaryExamples: dictionary at cambridge dot org

sense.def: used to show the cause of something, especially a feeling
dictionaryExamples: We were surprised at the news.
I was quite excited at the prospect.
Why does no one ever laugh at my jokes?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was very surprised at my English teacher, as she is an old lady and must be at least seventy years old. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: as much as, or more than, a number, amount, distance, etc.
dictionaryExamples: It will cost at least $500.
You'll have to wait at least an hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can write at least once a week. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used after an adjective to show a person's ability to do something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not very good at skiing.
He's very talented at math.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is really good at tennis. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type
dictionaryExamples: Are you sure I can't help at all?
He hasn't changed at all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sun was shining and there were no clouds at all, so we could see the light blue sky. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at the highest level of achievement or quality
dictionaryExamples: This article is an example of journalism at its best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoyed this trip because we got to stay in the countryside and [see] nature at its very best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: finally
dictionaryExamples: At last, I've found a pair of jeans that actually fit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At last, all of us agreed on "Cinema Farhang". Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: even if nothing else happens or is true
dictionaryExamples: If you don't have time to clean the whole house, at least make sure the kitchen is clean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could go shopping or at least go and have an ice-cream somewhere. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something that you say when you are telling someone about something good in a bad situation
dictionaryExamples: It's a small house but at least there's a backyard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not impressive but at least it has some things that I like. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
dictionaryExamples: At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first, when I arrived I was very nervous because I didn't know anyone, but then a girl started talking to me and I felt better. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If two things happen at the same time, they happen together.
dictionaryExamples: We arrived at the same time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The kind of clothes I most like [are] casual but fashionable at the same time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: I knew at once that I'd like it here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She called for an ambulance which came at once. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to reduce the effect of a statement
dictionaryExamples: I've met the President - at least, he shook my hand once.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But after years of developing my slalom, I wanted to learn something new, [s]o, I started Hot-Dogging. Hot-Dog is great fun.  At least, people say so. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to show a price, temperature, rate, speed, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He was driving at 120 mph when the police spotted him.

sense.def: If something must be done at all costs, it is very important that it is done.
dictionaryExamples: We have to succeed at all costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One thing was sure: he was convinced [he had] to save Anne's life at all costs. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: available for you to use at any time
dictionaryExamples: We will have a car at our disposal for the whole trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But on Wednesday morning I'm at your disposal. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: responsible for something bad that has happened
dictionaryExamples: I was the one at fault and I apologized.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really felt at fault.  First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: being in a situation where something bad is likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: All houses within 400 feet of the beach are at risk of flooding.
Releasing these prisoners puts the public at risk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lives are at risk! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If you do one thing at the expense of another, doing the first thing harms the second thing.
dictionaryExamples: He spent a lot of time at work, at the expense of his marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately one is usually done at the expense of the other. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it.
dictionaryExamples: You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.
These results should not be taken at face value - careful analysis is required to assess their full implications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People are assessed at face value [by] the type of cars they drive. International English Language Testing System; C1; Amharic

sense.def: If you see or understand something at a glance, you see or understand it almost immediately.
dictionaryExamples: He could tell at a glance that something was wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could tell at a glance that Peter was a loner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: near in time or space
dictionaryExamples: Teachers are always close at hand to give help to any child who needs it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I haven't had any lectures in English, but now and then there are lectures in English at the University so you need to understand the spoken language with no dictionary at hand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: not less than, and probably much more than
dictionaryExamples: At the very least, you should apologize.
We should earn $500 at the very least.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, I trust you will agree that at the very least I deserve a letter of explanation from you and a substantial refund of my money. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: chosen by chance
dictionaryExamples: Winners will be chosen at random.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rooms suggested to be [filmed] have not been chosen at random. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: sometimes
dictionaryExamples: At times, I wish I didn't have to go to school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: STUDYING METHODS All teachers at the college are high[ly] skilled professionals and can be very demanding at times, but this is [in] your best interest. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: when you first see or hear about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must admit that, at first sight, I did not feel like reading it, but later I made up my mind and decided to accept your invitation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
dictionaryExamples: If he drops the course now, at best he’ll get an incomplete, and he could fail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Then, due to the social standards, the old find themselves being abandoned and helpless. At best, such people are hospitalized. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionaryExamples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: having problems that other people do not have
dictionaryExamples: Being shy puts him at a disadvantage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These children are also at a disadvantage in term[s] of education, they may not be able to go to good school, engage in extracurricular activities like sports and music which can be quite expensive if you are living on a budget. International English Language Testing System; C2; Telugu

sense.def: in order to make someone look stupid
dictionaryExamples: Stop making jokes at my expense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But despite his intellectual superiority, Piggy was subject to derision because of his physical outward appearance and the group of boys played jokes at his expense. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If you have something at your fingertips, you can get it and use it very easily.
dictionaryExamples: He had all the information needed at his fingertips.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An Internet connection literally means having the world at your fingertips. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say what someone is really like
dictionaryExamples: I'm just a kid at heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also thought that she was brave at heart. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: most important in what is being discussed
dictionaryExamples: The point at issue is what is best for the child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wouldn't like to fall into the trap of generalizing the matter at issue, but I believe there are two ways of traveling. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: used after a time or date to say that something could happen before but not after that time
dictionaryExamples: She said to be there by 8 o'clock at the latest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as employment is concerned, as people take their pensions at the age of 65 at the latest, new staff cannot be recruited. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If you talk about something at length, you talk for a long time.
dictionaryExamples: We discussed both topics at length.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since we have already arranged for your family to come to stay in my home and discussed the arrangements at length and in detail, I will no longer bother you with terms of payment and other information that, judging by your letter, seems to be quite irrelevant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

blocks.phrase: be at liberty to do sth

sense.def: to be allowed to do something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not at liberty to discuss the matter at present.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On [the] one hand the child is at liberty to do whatever it pleases to do but on the other hand it was never taught the responsibilities implicit[l]y tied to such actions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: not knowing what to do
dictionaryExamples: I'm at a loss to explain his disappearance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And now I am comp[l]etely at a loss what to write next. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: not knowing what to say
dictionaryExamples: The question was unexpected and she was temporarily at a loss for words.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If it was James I would be at a loss for words, I didn't know what to tell him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrase: be at the mercy of sb/sth

sense.def: to not be able to protect yourself from something or someone that you cannot control
dictionaryExamples: Farmers are often at the mercy of the weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't believe I'd been careless enough to let them be at the mercy of Joanna's careless, boisterous friends, and I felt very lonely now, looking for them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to not agree with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The two brothers were always at odds.
His remark was at odds with our report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people are inexperienced as far as the world is concerned and thus they are frequently at odds with their family. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If something useful is at a premium, there is not enough of it.
dictionaryExamples: Time is at a premium just before the start of exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Honesty and accuracy are very good virtues to strive [for], but having friendship [and a] fair and caring relationship to your friend or partner have to be rated at a premium as well. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: used before saying what will happen if a situation continues in the same way
dictionaryExamples: At this rate we're not going to be there till midnight.

sense.def: used before saying one fact that is certain in a situation that you are generally not certain about
dictionaryExamples: Well, at any rate we need her to be there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, at any rate, we would like to see a society with [a] full and strong workforce working towards stronger economic power. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: If you do something at your own risk, you are completely responsible for anything bad that might happen because of it.
dictionaryExamples: Customers may leave vehicles here at their own risk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, when a young man decides to go on a dangerous expedition, he should do so at his own risk and should not rely on help from anyone. International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic

blocks.phrase: at the tender age of 8/17/25, etc.

sense.def: at the young age of 8/17/25, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She first appeared on stage at the tender age of 12.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She met my father at the tender age of 14, and she soon knew that this was the man she wanted to stay with for the rest of her life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: used to talk about an occasion in the past without saying exactly which occasion it was
dictionaryExamples: Most of us have made a similar mistake at one time or another.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Haven't we all at one time or another come home from a holiday feeling healthy and strong with a smile on our face thinking, this is what life is about. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If something is at stake, it is in a situation where it might be lost or damaged.
dictionaryExamples: We have to act quickly - people's lives are at stake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The whole human race's future is at stake. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a person who is very good at sports or physical exercise, especially one who competes in organized events
dictionaryExamples: He became a professional athlete at the age of 16.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's amazing what the athletes can do, don't you think? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: strong, healthy and good at sports
dictionaryExamples: She looks very athletic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, I am not only very athletic, but also really sociable and outgoing. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the feeling which  exists in a place or situation
dictionaryExamples: There's a very relaxed atmosphere in our office.
There has been an atmosphere of gloom in the factory since it was announced that it would be closing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll also love the friendly atmosphere here. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the mixture of gases around the Earth
dictionaryExamples: These factories are releasing toxic gases into the atmosphere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm against cars because their CO2 emissions destroy the atmosphere. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the air inside a room or other place
dictionaryExamples: The atmosphere in the room was so stuffy I could hardly breathe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The atmosphere in the halls also became hot and humid, thus making the whole experience rather unpleasant. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the smallest unit that an element can be divided into
dictionaryExamples: A molecule of carbon dioxide (CO2) has one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, the manager of that cent[er] called me in order to inform me that I would [be doing] research on nuclear power and atoms. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: using the energy that is created when an atom is divided
dictionaryExamples: atomic energy/power
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots more dangerous things in the world, like radioactive pol[l]ution or atomic bombs. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to connect or fix one thing to another
dictionaryExamples: I attached a photo to my application form.
Use this cable to attach the printer to the computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I attach my C.V. and I look forward to discussing it with you. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to connect a file, such as a document, picture or computer program, to an e-mail
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to send you some information about hotels attached to this mail. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to think that someone or something has importance/value, etc.
dictionaryExamples: You attach too much importance to money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father  knew exactly when he had to attach importance to feelings or emotions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to include something as part of something else
dictionaryExamples: There were too many conditions attached to the deal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, the aid provided to these countries is not always innocent and might have strings attached. International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic

sense.def: joined or connected to another thing
dictionaryExamples: Please fill out the attached form.
They live in the attached house across the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I am an athletic swimmer and a good surfer too, my choice from your attached list is naturally swimming and surfing. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: feeling emotionally close to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The children are very attached to their grandparents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My only concern is that she is a bit shy and very attached to her family, but I really don't think it would be a problem since she travels a lot and has already spent two months abroad. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: an extra piece of equipment that can be added to a machine
dictionaryExamples: This food processor has a special attachment for grinding coffee.

sense.def: a computer file that is sent together with an e-mail message
dictionaryExamples: I'll e-mail my report to you as an attachment.
I wasn't able to open that attachment.

sense.def: a feeling of love or strong connection to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She had a special attachment to these students.
I wasn't aware of any emotional attachment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite this impression she rejected her growing attachment to George in order to fulfil her family's expectation[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to try to hurt or defeat using violence
dictionaryExamples: He was attacked and seriously injured by a gang of youths.
Most wild animals won't attack unless they are provoked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At least he didn't attack me, and he even lent me his cell phone, he was such a gentle criminal. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to strongly criticize someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She attacked the government's new education policy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His behaviour was noticed, but the media could not attack such a successful negotiat[o]r. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: If a disease, chemical, etc., attacks someone or something, it damages it.
dictionaryExamples: The virus attacks the central nervous system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a myriad of diseases that attack the less protected. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a violent act intended to hurt or damage someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a racist attack
a terrorist attack on the capital
The town was once again under attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have planned to see "The attack of the super mutant aliens." Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you say something to strongly criticize someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a scathing attack on the president
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people often insist on doing everything on their own and consider advice almost an attack on their personal opinion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to achieve something, especially after a lot of work
dictionaryExamples: She's attained a high level of fitness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Alternatively, an English speaker from a non-English-speaking country may be of help only if he/she has attained a level higher than yours. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: possible to achieve
dictionaryExamples: We must ensure that we do not set ourselves goals that are not attainable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As electronic media sources have become more affordable and attainable, more people have access to local and international news and events. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: to try to do something, especially something difficult
dictionaryExamples: He attempted to escape through a window.
There's no point in even attempting an explanation - he'll never listen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was the second time I had attempted the exam. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: when you try to do something
dictionaryExamples: This is my second attempt at the exam.
They closed the road in an attempt  to reduce traffic in the city.
He made no attempt to be sociable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I made several attempts to make him change his mind, but I failed. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to go to an event, place, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Over two hundred people attended the funeral.
The meeting is on the fifth and we're hoping everyone will attend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I attend one of these activities, it was cricket, it was for the whole day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Urdu

sense.def: to go regularly to a place, such as a  particular school
dictionaryExamples: Which school does your daughter attend?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I attend Northampton College, which is quite far away from [my] house. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: the number of people who go to an event, meeting, etc.
dictionaryExamples: falling attendance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also in May, we had the swimming gala, which had a very high attendance from students as there were races for all abilities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you go somewhere such as a church, school, etc. regularly
dictionaryExamples: His attendance at school is very poor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently, I would make attendance more flexible for the members. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: present at an event
dictionaryExamples: They have doctors in attendance at every match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Professional coach[e]s are in attendance and the members can have proper lessons. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: when you watch, listen to, or think about something carefully or with interest
dictionaryExamples: Ladies and gentlemen, could I have your attention, please?
Wait a moment and I'll give you my full attention.
After an hour, my attention started to wander.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your attention. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to watch, listen to, or think about something carefully
dictionaryExamples: You weren't paying attention to what I was saying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Larry is a very distracted boy. Everybody says that he should pay attention to what he is doing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone notice you
dictionaryExamples: I waved at her to get her attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bank is near the school, so the lady was trying to get people's attention while the others [robbed] the bank. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone notice something or someone
dictionaryExamples: If I could just draw your attention to the second paragraph.
She's always drawing attention to herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The purpose of his report is to draw attention to videos in English. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to receive more attention than anyone or anything else
dictionaryExamples: He loves to be the center of attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He would have so much fun being the center of attention. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a space in a house just under the roof, often used for storing things
dictionaryExamples: There's a large room and additional storage space in the attic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had no idea how but she knew she had all the luck she could ever get, from the very old lucky rabbit foot she found up in the attic yesterday. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: how you think or feel about something, and how this makes you behave
dictionaryExamples: He has a very bad attitude to/toward work.
That boy has a real attitude problem.
She has a very positive attitude generally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The waiters had a very good attitude toward the customers and the food was really wonderful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a lawyer who represents people in legal matters or speaks for them in court
dictionaryExamples: a defense attorney
a civil/criminal attorney
He has been named the new district attorney.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An in[n]ocent man is arrested and the court ap[p]oints an attorney to defend him. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to make people come to a place or do a particular thing by being interesting, enjoyable, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The castle attracts more than 300,000 visitors a year.
The circus is attracting huge crowds/audiences.
We need to attract more bright young people to teaching.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it was the first time that I came to this new class, it attracted me deeply. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to cause people to pay attention/be interested, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Her ideas have attracted a lot of attention in the scientific community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I go out with my friends I actually like wearing clothes that attract people's attention. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to like someone because of the way they look or behave
dictionaryExamples: I was attracted to him straight away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was really attracted to him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that makes people come to a place or do a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: tourist attractions
The opportunity to travel is one of the main attractions of this job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first I only wanted to see the many attractions in Balboa Park. Preliminary English Test; B1; Dutch

sense.def: when you like someone, especially romantically, because of the way they look or behave
dictionaryExamples: We had a strong mutual attraction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ever since the begi[n]ning, since the day when Olivia met the Nawab for the first time, she felt an [i]nexplicable attraction toward him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: beautiful or pleasant to look at
dictionaryExamples: an attractive woman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very small but attractive. Key English Test; A2; Bulgarian

sense.def: interesting or useful
dictionaryExamples: an attractive offer/idea
We want to make the club attractive to a wider range of people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your big library where you might find some books that are not available in other libraries is undoubtedly very attractive for anyone who loves literature. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a sale in which things are sold to the person who offers the most money
dictionaryExamples: The furniture was sold at auction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And funds could be raised for the changes by [hold]ing auctions, runs, parties, raffles, contests etc.  Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the people who sit and watch a performance at a theater, hall, outdoors, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There were a lot of children in the audience.
The audience was clearly enjoyed the performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the [people in the] audience looked at me, I was very excited. The band called me, so I went to the stage and they started to play a very popular song. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the type of people who watch a particular TV show, read a particular book, etc.
dictionaryExamples: This magazine is aimed at a teenage/young audience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The above-mentioned restaurants are totally different from each other and suit completely different customers. Pasta, to begin with, is best suited [to a] younger audience. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when someone does a short performance to try to get a job as an actor, singer, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She's got an audition for the show.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many [un]talented pe[ople] think they can sing and attend the auditions, but others laugh at them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the eighth month of the year, after July and before September
dictionaryExamples: the 13th of August/August 13(th)
We've got friends coming at the end of August.
They got married last August.
They're getting married next August.
It was one of the hottest Augusts on record.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jo: The class is going to be the 9th of August. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the sister of someone's father or mother, or the wife of someone's uncle
dictionaryExamples: I have an aunt in Australia.
Auntie Camille
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My uncle, my aunt, my cousin and my friends (Renata, Gustavo, John, Paul) came to the party. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: If something is authentic, it is real, true, or what people say it is.
dictionaryExamples: authentic Italian food
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am also nostalgic for authentic Thai culture which has subtly and gradually been replaced by American and European culture. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: the writer of a book, article, play, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He is the author of two books on French history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During [the] Easter holiday, I read a very good thriller by an Italian author, Andrea Camilleri. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the power to make decisions or to control other people
dictionaryExamples: The United Nations has used its authority to restore peace in the area.
We need to get the support of someone in authority.
They have the authority to examine the company's records.
The problem is that teachers feel they no longer have authority over their pupils.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their parents have lost almost all their authority. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: someone  with official power to control a particular type of activity
dictionaryExamples: local/health/school autorities
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Air pollution and traffic congestions are major issues that have been raised by local authorities very recently. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: someone who has a lot of knowledge about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: She is an authority on seventeenth-century English literature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read the book more than six times and I became an authority on [the] Roman Empire. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to give official permission for something
dictionaryExamples: His manager had authorized the expenditure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we do that, every piece of data is stored in a place acce[s]sible for anyone authorized, for example, you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to be officially allowed to do something
dictionaryExamples: Only managers are authorized to sign expense forms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my capacity as the secretary of the Social Club, I am authorized to express students' dissatisfaction with the facilities of the museum and to urge you to take remedial action toward improving the situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: An automatic machine works by itself or with little human control.
dictionaryExamples: automatic doors
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has both manual and automatic functions so it has a lot of possibilities. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: done as a natural reaction, without thinking
dictionaryExamples: My automatic response was to pull my hand away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her gesture was almost automatic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: certain to happen as part of the normal process or system
dictionaryExamples: You get an automatic promotion after two years.

sense.def: If a machine does something automatically, it does it independently, without human control.
dictionaryExamples: The camera adjusts the shutter speed automatically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] television will be automatically switched on in time for [the] breakfast news. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If you do something automatically, you do it without thinking about it.
dictionaryExamples: I automatically put my hand out to catch it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was a strange envelope between the others, so automatically, she picked it up and [looked at] the stamp. The letter came from Australia. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: when something or someone is available
dictionaryExamples: I checked the availability of flights online and there's plenty of choice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, it is essential that you take account of my availability when booking the trip. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: able to be bought, used, or gotten
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any double rooms available this weekend?
Is this dress available in a larger size?
My new novel will be available in bookstores this week.
The information is available on the Internet.
There are computers available at the library for public use.
I'm afraid I'm not available to help with the show on the 19th.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to know more details and what facilities are available. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Somali

sense.def: If someone is available, they are not busy and so are able to do something.
dictionaryExamples: Are you available next weekend?
No one from the company was available to comment on the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am available any time. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a street, often a wide one, in a city or town
dictionaryExamples: Michigan Avenue in Chicago is famous for its elegant stores.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The demonstrators just spread litter all over the largest and finest avenue. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a possible way of doing or achieving something
dictionaryExamples: We have exhausted all other avenues of treatment.

sense.def: typical and usual
dictionaryExamples: The average person in the street is a lot better off than they were forty years ago.
a student of average ability
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This makes people beli[e]ve that a lot of the food we eat is fast-food, but it's not true at all, in fact it's a very small part of our average diet. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: An average number is the number you get by adding two or more amounts together and dividing the total by the number of amounts.
dictionaryExamples: an average age/temperature
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather on this mountain is fantastic, with an average temperature of 17°C. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: not particularly good
dictionaryExamples: The meal  was pretty average.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't get the high standard [of] service that you had offered me, and the food was pretty average. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the result you get by adding two or more amounts together and dividing the total by the number of amounts
dictionaryExamples: Prices have risen by an average of 4% over the past year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the table was my mark sheet with the average as 90%. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: the usual or typical amount
dictionaryExamples: An 8-hour working day is about the average.
The audience figures were lower than average for this sort of film.
The quality of candidates was (well)below/above average.
I expect to spend an average of $20 for a meal in a restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [don't] have much time to watch TV and I only spend an average of two to five hours [a] week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: usually, or based on an average
dictionaryExamples: Female workers earn, on average, a third less than men.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On average, our pupils are 16 years old and they join actively in all the events we organi[z]e. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to stay away from a person, place, situation, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I try to avoid going downtown on  the weekend.
Do you think Tim's avoiding me? I haven't seen him all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People despise and avoid her because she is ugly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to prevent something from happening
dictionaryExamples: I left the room to avoid a fight.
Unnecessary paperwork should be avoided at all costs.
The plane narrowly avoided disaster when one of the engines failed on take-off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that all these problems could have been avoided and that asking [for] my money back is the best way of forgetting that evening. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to intentionally not do something
dictionaryExamples: She managed to avoid answering my question.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The writer avoided d[e]scribing personal thoughts. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: not sleeping
dictionaryExamples: I find it so difficult to stay awake late.
I drink a coffee to keep me awake.
I lay awake half the night worrying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt so nervous that it kept her awake at night. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be completely awake
dictionaryExamples: "Is Oliver awake yet?" "Yes, he's wide  awake and running around his bedroom."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes, when I have put my children to bed, half an hour later an aircraft flies over and my two-year old daughter is wide awake again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to give money or a prize following an official decision
dictionaryExamples: He was awarded the Nobel Prize for physics.
The university has awarded her a $500 travel grant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you will see, I was awarded a grade A. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a prize given to someone for something they have achieved
dictionaryExamples: the Academy Award for Best Director
Both films have received/won several awards.
